channel.title: Sakai
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of some issues

item.title: [REQ-1] Selective release of assignments in Gradebook
item.description:
Instructors can decide whether or not to release any assignment column to students either while creating the assignment or any time after it has been created.
Instructors can hide any assignment column at any time after it has been released.
item.summary: Selective release of assignments in Gradebook

comments.comment: This feature should probably be framed within a larger "selective release" feature set. Selective release should be configurable not only on grade columns and assignments, but on quizzes, discussions, resources (e.g. reading material) or any other content. For example, selective release features should allow an instructor to specify that particular reading material in the course will not be made available to the student until the student has scored above a certain amount of points on a test.
Assigning to Luke for review.

Potentially, the release widget might ultimately incorporate this issue. It already includes many other components. Need to learn more about what their scope is when talking about material created in Sakai. [Note to myself to ask Daphne off-line.]
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-2] Gradebook Export More Configurable
item.description:
Spreadsheet export should be configurable to meet, for instance, local registrar system requirements for grade submissions

1. System administrator can configure the course grade spreadsheet export to meet local institutional format and data requirements for course grade submissions to the registrar's system.
2. Instructor can export and download all course grade data to a single file that does not require further editing (assuming all required data can be provided by Sakai) before it is submitted to the registrar's system.
item.summary: Gradebook Export More Configurable

comments.comment: UC Berkeley's Registrar requires that the letter grade a student taking a class pass/not pass would have achieved be submitted as part of the final grade. Sakai will need to support a student grading option status in order to meet REQ-2. The currently unused Sakai Course Management API would do this.

A related longer term requirement: "Instructor can export course grade data directly to the registrar's system through the Sakai user interface while meeting all local institutional requirements for course grade submissions." I believe Indiana has or is in the process of implementing this requirement locally with an eye towards eventually generalizing their solution.
Assigning to Luke for review.
Reassigning to Owen.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-3] Gradebook should focus on getting data in
item.description:
The current gradebook seems to focus much of its attention on evaluating scores, i.e. presenting % of right, current cumulative grade, etc. Given limited manpower, it should be focused on gathering data. Faculty use different ways of combining scores. Some are incredibly subjective. Many of them don't want to show anything other than scores on assignments. Those that would be happy to show a cumulative grade would need great flexiblity in how it's calculated, such as weighting, dropping lowest assignments, etc. But those faculty say they would be happy to download the data to excel, do calculations there, and upload the actual grade. Thus what we need is:

* The ability to disable showing anything other than raw scores
* Accurate scores from tests/quizzes and assignments
* An additional column next to the username that can be loaded by the external providers with an institutional ID (typically student number). This is needed to let us corollate data in Sakai with data in University student systems, which operate by ID number rather than Sakai username.
* Ability to upload a column of data from a spreadsheet or other external source [would need to upload 2 columns, the data plus the username]
* Ability to create a column via a web service, so we can feed from other systems [ex: attendance taking]
* Ability to delete a column
* Ability to move columns
* Ability to assign categories to columns (e.g. to separate test, homework and attendance) and to use those to group display if desired
* Ability to add text columns or some other way to provide explanations of special cases for students
item.summary: Gradebook should focus on getting data in

comments.comment: I said we needed it within a year. However it's important for us to be able to tell faculty sooner what is happening to the Gradebook. This is in fact a general issue with us: In many cases the time critical thing is a commitment, not when the feature is released.

Ditto - on all of Charles' points, especially the info in the narrative and the first two bullet items. We need the gradebook to provide raw scores at this time and not attempt to evaluate learner performance since higher level functionatliy (weighting of scores, dropping lowest scores, ec.) is not in place and would take much longer to be implemented. We, too, need accurate scores from tests & quizzes AND the assignments tool, ASAP. Of even more critical importance to adoption of Sakai by our users is the integration of the assignments tool with the gradbook. This must happen with half a year (in time for fall productions). The gradebook needs to "mature" to provide the grading options presently available in the assignments tool. The assignments tool, optionally, should send the raw scores/grades to the gradebook.

This sounds like a sensible prioritization. All this said, we shouldn't lose track, long term, of the need to include advanced gradebook functionality (e.g. running scores, formulas and weighting, dropping lowest or earliest score, automatically populating a grade with 0 if a due date is past). This type of functionality can't be duplicated with ease in Excel and many of our faculty are used to having it available in our homegrown online gradebooks. In fact, many of our faculty who've moved to WebCT Vista 3.0 have been frustrated that these features don't exist yet in our WebCT deployment. So long term it would be a good idea (for our faculty at least) if this functionality was incorporated into Sakai.
Assigning to Luke for review.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-4] Allow users to specify their default WYSIWYG editor preference
item.description:
Allow users to select the WYSIWYG editor of their choice (HtmlArea, FCK Editor, Sferyx, etc.). This could be surfaced under Prefereces. The setting should make their editor of choice the default in all Sakai tools in the user's sites. (This setting presumes that a Sakai tools' functionality will not be dependent on a particular WYSIWYG editor.) It may also be desirable to have the list of possible WYSIWYG editors configurable as a system-wide setting, i.e., in the sakai.properties file.

Use Cases:

* Scientific users might want a WYSIWYG with good equation support.

* Project site users might want a WYSIWYG with complex formating support.

* Foreign language users might want a WYSIWYG with good spell-checking and internationalization support.

* Support resources maybe limited, so one might want to limit the number of different WYSIWYG editors on a system-wide basis.
item.summary: Allow users to specify their default WYSIWYG editor preference

comments.comment: I am not so sure that this is a good idea. For large installations, the technical support costs of this much flexibility may be a problem. Since the editor is used nearly everywhere it is very bad for it to enxperience problems. Perhaps a compromise is that Sakai has a system-side configuration option that determines the set of possible editors. If the configuration option only specifies one editor, users are not given the choice.

Giving users lots of editors may be an issue. However I do thing we want at least some choice. Scientific users will want something with good equation support. This may result in a heavy-weight editor such as Sferyx that other users will not want. In fact there are several different approaches to equation editing, and users may need to pick one. Another approach is to provide a single editor, but have buttons that let the user call a specific equation editor as needed.

No, I wouldn't support giving users too many editor choices. I can imagine the support nightmares. I was thinking about two choices - a light option and a robust option. For some users (and disciplines), an editor like sferyx is not necessary. Others would prefer to use a light weight editor, like FCK. But in some subjects, like in mathematics, foreign languages, etc. instructors can't work without an editor like sferyx. Even in subjects where a powerful editor is not necessary, we are finding that some users like access to a powerful editor for webdav support, spell-checking, etc. and are asking for this option! Again, a couple of good editor choices would be nice - and if that's not possible, perhaps we can achieve the same results (satisfy the needs of a wide range of users) in another way. The need is there.

I guess that a good compromise here is in the properties file let the installing person specifiy a list of the editors which they wanted to make available. If the system installer only put in one, then this preference would not appear. If there was more than one then users could pick amongst the options. Then we have our cake and eat it too. For smaller groups like scientists as Charles H suggests, they might not get confused. For 100,000 users - one choice is the best bet.
Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
Reviewed by "Worksite & Admin Tools".

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-5] Site Usage Statistics Tool
item.description:
Our version of Blackboard has a tool which instructors prize: it generates reports of site usage and activity. The different sorts of things they can learn from this tool may stand as use cases:
- A breakdown (pie chart) of which areas of the site have been accessed most often
- A breakdown of site visits by hour of the day or day of the week
- The ability to constrain the dates of the reporting (e.g. how many students went to the discussion board during the week preceding the mid-term)
- The ability to constrain the reporting to a single student or subset of students

These reports have served a valuable diagnostic role for instructors rethinking the use of their sites. But it might also be useful to extend this reporting for department administrators or support staff, covering a set of sites or even the system as a whole.

Using a worksite statistics tool, a maintainer, instructor or admin could determine who has accessed the worksite and what was accessed for a specified time period. The statistics would be reported by the tool in the forms of tabular data as well as graphical bar charts.

The worksite statistics tool would allow the instructor to specify which statistics to query, such as:
Start Date
End Date
Users (individual, multiple selections, or all)
Area (individual, multiple selections, or all)

Areas that would be queried for statistics would include:
Announcements
Assignments
Chat Room
Discussion Board
Gradebook
Presentation
Resources
Schedule
Syllabus
Test & Quizzes
Web Content
item.summary: Site Usage Statistics Tool

comments.comment: I agree. Many of our faculty are really after us about this. We probably can't do a final cutover to Sakai without it. Our faculty seem to want two different things: * the ability to see which parts of the site have been used * the ability to see what specific students have done. They want to be able to see whether students have looked at readings, etc. This is an area where individual institutions are likely to need to tailor things. I'd try to do a fairly general tool that lets people design their own reports. One approach would be to make the data available via SQL and depend upon a good general-purpose SQL report generator. Report generation is a specialized function where lots of work has been done. It may not make sense for the Sakai community to duplicate this work. I haven't assessed the tools, but I'd assume there would be an open source tool we could use.

We, at University of Lleida (Spain), have make a tool that shows, for each student in a course, the global number of visits to the course for the student and the last visit time. When you click on a specific user, you can view all the visits relative to this student. We have make it using the information stored by presence tool.
This gap is similar to a few of the Sakai 2.2 requirements REQ-330 REQ-5 REQ-88

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-7] Gradebook as grading schema provider/helper
item.description:
Since grading schemas can be common across multiple tools, I think gradebook should provide a service and/or a helper tool so that other tools can draw from some common set of grading schemas. Such a service should provide a way to define a customizable and extendable set of schemas. Other tools then can incorporate this functionality or build upon it, instead of writing tool-specific schemas. Users, administrators and developers of the system benefit when common tasks are handled in a uniform manner (they don't have to recreate grading schemas for different tools, with potentially unfamiliar UI's).

It would be nice if the common set of grading schemas was easily configurable, perhaps similar to the way other lists of things are handled in sakai.properties. For example,

gradescales.count=4
gradescale.1=A,B,C,D,I,W
gradescale.2=Pass,Fail
gradescale.3=A+,A,A-,B+,B,B-,C+,C,C-,D+,D,D-,F
gradescale.4=5,4,3,2,1

and then Assignments, Gradebook, T&Q would provide those scales for use and limit the acceptable values to those specified when the scale is not a point range.
item.summary: Gradebook as grading schema provider/helper

comments.comment: It would be nice if the common set of grading schemas was easily configurable, perhaps similar to the way other lists of things are handled in sakai.properties. For example, gradescales.count=4 gradescale.1=A,B,C,D,I,W gradescale.2=Pass,Fail gradescale.3=A+,A,A-,B+,B,B-,C+,C,C-,D+,D,D-,F gradescale.4=5,4,3,2,1 and then Assignments, Gradebook, T&Q would provide those scales for use and limit the acceptable values to those specified when the scale is not a point range.
Assigning to Luke for review.
Nicely put, John. I was just commenting in SAK-3839 about a possibly related need for this kind of configuration for international adopters of the gradebook.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-8] Need the ability to deny permissions
item.description: A deny permission is needed in order to be able to control read/write access to subfolders. Without it, read access to a subfolder can't be prevented since you can't take away a permission granted at the parent folder, and in order to get to the subfolder, you need readd access at the parent. A deny capability would also be useful in conjunction with the !site.helper realm, to deny certain permissions to a role in all sites. See SAK-1609 for further details.
item.summary: Need the ability to deny permissions

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-9] Structuring content for presentation
item.description:
Current the Resources tool is the only place other than Melete where we can put content. Many faculty want the ability to structure the way material is presented. The commercial tools all have some way to construct an "organizer page" (called different things) where items can be placed. Unlike the current Resources tool, organizer pages are constructed to present content rather than maintain it. So an entry will normally have a title and a description, but not the various icons present in Resources.

I am not sure whether the right way to do this is to provide an alternative view into Resources folders or a completely separate tool. However I suspect that it makes sense to use the resources tool for maintenance, to avoid giving faculty two different ways to do essentially the same thing.

Faculty see the left margin as part of the way content is organized. Thus we also need a tool for adding items and changing the order in the left margin. I would try to make that interface look as close as possible to the interface for maintaining organizer pages.

Which ever approach you take, here are some things needed for the organizer page:

* items should be any of the items in a current resources folder; plus pointers to any tool, and to individual entries such as an assignment, a discussion item, an RSS item, another organizer page or a quiz; plus choices from a set of items defined by the local administrator (links to the Library and other common things at the University)
* it must be easy to change the order of items on the page
* there should be a choice of presenting items in a Sakai iframe or in a new window
* it must be easy to put a link from the left margin to one of these pages
* it must be easy to change the order of items in the left margin
* for items in the left margin it shoulbe possible to choose whether to present the item in a Sakai iframe or a new window

If you create a new tool for this, i.e. you leave the current Resources tool alone, faculty will still want the ability to control the order in which items in resources are presented.

I am also concerned about the ability to share content in Resources and other content presentation. Not all content is specific to an individual course. E.g. our language departments have constructed an environment where students see content from a course, from the specific language department, and from the system as a whole.

We need a place to maintain shared content (an obvious choice would be a site not associated with any one course), and the following sorts of facilities:

* something like a symbolic link, that would let a course import either individual items or whole resource folders/organizer pages, and get the current version even if it changes. It must be possible to put such links in the left margin or on organizer pages.
* the ability to import portions of the left margin (actually, it might be better to have the ability to put it somewhere else, such as the right margin). To see what I'm looking for, take a look at http://fas-digiclass.rutgers.edu/page.jsp?dept=french The "reference" section on the right should show in all French courses. [At some point we're going to have to move this site into Sakai. At the moment I don't think we could do it.]

Some thought needs to go into authorization. While a lot of the shared material is public, we need to assume that not all of it will be. The lowest level of authorization would be attaching a list of rosters to the shared sites. This could be done simply by making them course sites. However there are issue with this. (1) The maintaners of these sites are not always authorized to see the students in all the rosters. (2) Maintain a list of all individual sections using the shared content could become burdensome. You'd really like the ability to define one or most sites that can use the shared content, with the ability for course sites to use wildcards (so you can say any site associated with a course in a specific discipline).
item.summary: Structuring content for presentation

comments.comment: When I ask for the ability to import part of the margin, it is not good enough simply to provide a template, i.e. a sample that has the right items in the margin, which people can use in building a new course. The problem is that the French department may need to update their list of resources. So we need this to be a link to something in a shared site.

This requirement includes features that are parts of other requirements: REQ-40-integration of groups with resources; REQ-378-ordering of resources. REQ-60-allow folders to be visible to multiple sites. However, there is much here that is not included in those REQs.
related to REQ-9 on structuring content for presentation
Related to REQ-111. Maybe these are alternative descriptions for the same requirement(s)?

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-10] Support for HTML editors
item.description:
There have been reports that you are going to provide a single place for interfacing HTML editors. We certainly need this. However we need more than just a place to plug in an editor. We also need some facilities in the core to support an HTML editor. Here are some things we've found that we need. In reading these requirements, note that the HTML editor will be used for preparing HTML pages in Resources, but also portions of pages in announcements, quizes, etc.

* a file picker. People want to put links in their HTML document. Most HTML editors have buttons to insert a normal link and an image. Many HTML editors have a "browse" button in the tools. We need a URL that the browse function can go to. At a minimum that should give you a directory listing of Resources, with a button next to each item that lets you choose it in Javascript. It might be a good idea for the file picker to be able to choose among several different areas, e.g. Resources for the course, for the faculty member creating the page, and from sites in which shared content is housed.

* support for HTML editors that create images and equations. This includes support for uploading files through HTTP POST. However you should also consider where images should go. The obvious approach is an images folder in Resources. However there are reasons for students not to be able to get a listing of images. If you are preparing a test, images may include equations and other items that would help a student guess what is going to be on the test. Either you need to be able to protect the images directory in resources from browsing by students, or it should go in a separate place which the faculty member can browse but the student cannot.
item.summary: Support for HTML editors

comments.comment: Improve the HTML editor deals with the requeriments associated.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-12] Sakai Import and Export using IMS Content Packaging
item.description:
Sakai currently uses its own proprietary import and export. It would be nice to support IMS Content Packaging import/export in Sakai as well. An imprortant first-step is support for the IMS Common Cartridge, which is a profile of IMS Content Packaging.

Use Case:

* Import and export content using IMS Content Packing.
item.summary: Sakai Import and Export using IMS Content Packaging

comments.comment: Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
Reviewed by "Worksite & Admin Tools".
The IMS Common Cartridge effort is underway and Sakai hopes to have a demonstration of the implementation of IMS Common Cartridge by the Summer Alt-i-lab meeting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)
Any new tool needing import/export support

item.title: [REQ-14] Sakai services should minimize dependencies and references to other services
item.description: Sakai services should strive to model data management for a set of objects and minimize the use of other Sakai services in both the API and implementations. By clearly separating concerns, this will lead to Sakai services being more modular and easier to adapt services for enterprise integration. Since Sakai services are layered, no sakai service should ever reference a higher level service. Even references at the same level should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.
item.summary: Sakai services should minimize dependencies and references to other services

comments.comment: Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-15] Comprehensive 'remove user' functionality
item.description:
There is a need for a more comprehensive "remove user" fucntionality than currently exists. One that not only deletes the user, but all the appropriate, associated data, such as their MyWorkspace site, their memberships, etc., rather than leaving it orphaned in the db. Note that for some cases, such as users from external providers, it may not be desireable to delete all the related artifacts when deleting the internal user representation in Sakai, so support should be provided for both the current and the proposed delete user functionality. This likely to be a larger problem in projects than in course sites, where users from outside the orginization are likely to be using guest accounts.

Use Cases:

* Deleting a user and all their associated material
* Deleting just the Sakai, internal user account, but not their associated material

----------------------------------------
Original Description:

When a user is deleted through the GUI (Users tool, 'Remove user'), not all artefacts and associations of the user are removed. For example, the user's my workspace site remains, as does realm membership or any sites of which the user was a member.

In some cases, this behaviour is desirable (for example where a user was created internally but also exists through a provider), whereas in other cases it is undesirable, leaves behind orphaned data in the db and/or may have security implications (OOTB configurations and configurations where userids of internal users may not be unique across the lifespan of the application, e.g. guest accounts where the email address is the userid).

The issues are described further in these JIRA items:

http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-655
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-1535
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-1456
http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-2973

A more comprehensive 'remove user' capability is required (whether invoked via the GUI, web services or API), which is flexible or configurable enough to cope with various deployment scenarios, i.e. ways in which the Sakai internal user db and external providers interact.
item.summary: Comprehensive 'remove user' functionality

comments.comment: Related to this, but perhaps a separate issue, is what to do with users' artifacts from tools that are removed from a site. Should there be a difference between deleting a tool form a site and removing it (hiding the tool and its content)? Should artiifacts be completely deleted when a tool is deleted or removed? Should artifacts be hidden, but if the tool is re-added, then the previous content is still there? (Gives an easy way to recover from accidently removing a tool.) Should artifacts be hidden, but if the tool is re-added, then a choice presented for starting fresh or restoring previous content? (Gives an easy way to clean out a tool, such as when new instructors explore their site by creating junk content when they are getting used to Sakai or starting a new term.)
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-16] Template capability for email messages
item.description:
In cases where Sakai sends outgoing email messages and possibly in some other instances, blocks of text are constructed in java code. This means that for sites to customize the text of email messages (whether for language translation or local context), it is necessary to change the java source code, rebuild and redeploy.

It would be significantly simplify Sakai deployment and subsequent customization if email messages could be generated from templates. This would allow templates to be customized either in the filesystem, or through the UI itself if the templates were stored in the database or ContentHosting. A case where the latter might be desirable is to allow site owners to customize the email invitation sent when adding new guest users to a site.

A generic templating capability would allow a template which included replaceable parameters identified by name, e.g.

-------
Dear $Firstname,

Welcome to the $SiteFullName worksite on $SakaiServiceName.
...
-------
item.summary: Template capability for email messages

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-19] Make storage and display of assessment scores consistent
item.description:
1: Scores should be stored and transmitted between tools (as opposed
to displayed) with the highest possible accuracy (i.e. doubles).

2: The default display of scores should be 2 decimal places. For
example, 1 out of 3 is displayed as ".33"
item.summary: Make storage and display of assessment scores consistent

comments.comment: Assigning to Luke for review.
Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component

Assignments, Tests & Quizzes (Samigo), and Gradebook currently store and display point-based assessment values in different maners. A recent discussion in the email thread in sakai- assessment@collab.sakaiproject.org called "Consistant grading (SAK-2848)" illustrated why this is a problem and had the above consensus. To see the majority of this thread/discussion please see the attached file (above) consistentGradingTread.rtf. ----------------------------- Original Description: Assignments, Tests & Quizzes (Samigo), and Gradebook currently store and display point-based assessment values in different maners. The recent discussion in the email thread in the "Sakai DG: Assessment Tools" illustrates why this is important and suggests appropriate resolutions. Exisiting assessment tools and any new related tools should conform as best as possible to a standard approach to point-based storage and display. In particular, the developing consensus for storing point-based assessments values appears to be doubles. By storing with as much percision as possible, then round-off errors are less likely to generate confusion for students and instructors. For the display of points, the developing consensus is for two decimal places. This will help also help reduce confusion related to round-off errors. For example, 0.33 or 0.67 perhaps more clearly indicate you received one-third or two-thirds of a point, respectively, on an assessment item. A desire for configuring the number of decimal places, at the system-wide and/or site-wide levels, has also been expressed; as has the desire not to allow such configuration.
Ready for Voting

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-20] Standardize URL input fields
item.description: Different validation rules and hints are applied to URL input fields across the various tools in Sakai, such as automatically adding http:// or not, pre-loading the input field with the http:// prefix, etc. It would be nice to standarize the rules, at least for the core/bundeled tool set.
item.summary: Standardize URL input fields

comments.comment: Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
Added to JSF component
Added style guide as a component. Once decisions are made about the rules they should be added to the style guide.
UI Team has reviewed this.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)
Any new tool with URL input fields

item.title: [REQ-21] Standard Calendar Widget
item.description: Tools should strive to use a common date-time picker or calendar widget. For example, Schedule, Assignments, and Tests & Quizzes (Samigo) all use a different approach right now. The attached document points out some of the differences in how the calendar widget works in several Sakai tools. This requirement would change the style guide suggestion for the calendar widget and create a Sakai JSF widget which can be shared by all tools that use calendaring.
item.summary: Standard Calendar Widget

comments.comment: Attached document Vivie describing and displaying the 4 different behaviors.
Assigning to Luke for review.
Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component

The attached document points out some of the differences in how the calendar widget works in several Sakai tools. This requirement would change the style guide suggestion for the calendar widget and create a Sakai JSF widget which can be shared by all tools that use calendaring.
UI Group is done with this one.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)
Any new tool which needs a calendar widget

item.title: [REQ-23] Support for directly entering images and rich text in "Worksite Information"
item.description:
Site owners often want to include a richer description of their course or project besides just text. While one could currently do this by creating an HTML document outside of Sakai or in the site's Resources, and then using the URL, it would be better practice to be able to create and edit such a rich Worksite Information page in the tool itself, or when editing or creating the Descirption initially in Site Info or Worksite Setup.

Use Cases:

* Site owners would like to create and edit "Worksite Information" that includes rich text and images.

----------------------------
Original Description:

Faculty at UC Berkeley would like to be able to add images and rich text to the descriptions of their sites. Many consider the ability to place image(s) on the HOME page an important feature that is currently missing from bSpace. They would like to be able to better personalize their sites with image(s) that represent their classes/subject matter.
item.summary: Support for directly entering images and rich text in "Worksite Information"

comments.comment: Jeff, currently a user can place such content on the Home page by adding it to the "Worksite Information" part, though in a rather convoluted manner; they can create an HTML page in Resources (or even outside Sakai for that matter) and enter its URL in Worksite Information's options. So, picking up on your "better personalize" phrasing, how were do we need to improve upon this existing functionality? Would the requirement be satisfied by adding the option to the existing "Worksite Information" for directly creating richer content using the WYSIWYG editor, or is there more to this than that?

Peter, Faculty members I've talked to don't need anything too fancy: Just the ability to add a single image to Worksite Information (an image which they feel represents the class), and edit the text with the Rich Text options found elsewhere in Sakai tools. As far as implementation of this, I see it as simply a button labeled "Add image" and a text box with Rich Text options.

For reference, attached is a screenshot of an example use case of what one might be trying to do. (In this case I created an HTML page with images on a separate web server and put the URL into Worksite Information. It would've been nicer and easier, however, to just create it by editing the options for Worksite Information.)

Yes, this is the use I had in mind. However, so that faculty would not have to even consider layout, I was thinking it would be easiest just to have an image above and text below. For a class on Mayan art, for example, there would be an image of a Mayan sculpture and below it, the descriptive text for the course.

Okay, so the key is as easy as possible :) Check out the WYSIWYG editor in Sakai's Tests & Quizzes (Samigo) tool, which let's you insert images; you don't need to worry about the layout unless you want to. If that's too complex of a solution to this, however, then perhaps the option should be to support uploading a single image and typing some text in a field that would appear below the image. Either way, it sounds like using the Worksite Information potion of the page is okay.

Yes! The WYSIWYG editor in Tests & Quizzes looks perfect! However, when I tried inserting an image, it looked like the only option was to provide a URL. I think it would be necessary to be able to BROWSE for the image as well.

At Portland State University, this issue is moving beyond simply adding images to the homepage. Several faculty members want an icon-bank similar to WebCT, and with that, the ability to post icons on the homepage. I have never been a big fan, and I'm unaware of a correlation between learning and icons and or images on the homepage. However, some of these requests are coming from users with special needs - specifically those with limited vision. They like a large image that directs them to the discussion board, chat, gradebook, etc. So, I am beginning to rethink the way I feel about this issue. :)

Vincent, the functionality you describe sounds interesting, but distinct from the focus of Jeff's requirement. You should create a separate requirement for it, if it is functionality you are intereseted in seeing in Sakai.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

Some additional use case descriptions from REQ-327 (duplicate) by Juliette Mai: Instructors often like to upload an image as well as a link to an external web site that they've created on the course home page. It would be nice to allow instructors the ability to do the following on Worksite Information: -upload an image (image usually reflects theme of course) -provide a link to an external web site (e.g., http://www.stanford.edu/~bio101/) that contains supplemental course materials

item.title: [REQ-25] View Site as if in a Different Role
item.description:
The ability for a user to view the site as it would be viewed by a user with a different role in the site. For example, an instructor being able to view a site as their students see it.

This is similar to, but not the same as the SUTool, which allows admin users to view the site as a specific user would see it.

comments.comment: General use case derived from REQ-206 [closed]: "Allow instructors to easily see what students see and do in their site. This includes letting the instructor see what a particular page would look like from the students perspective along with allowing them complete an activity (like turn in an assignment) as if someone in the student role would. Instructors should be able to switch between theirs and the students view quickly and easily. Clearly let the instructor know if they are looking at the site as a student. This requirement should help instructors feel more confident that the CMS will not make them look stupid or unprofessional in the students eyes."

General use case provided in REQ-180: "The goal I've entered below specifically states that an instructor should be able to enter a site as a student, but this functionality shouldn't be limited to the instructor/student role. Any author should be able to view the site from any role. Goals: Instructor can enter site as a student and see the site materials exactly as a student would."

Some external scheduling applications also have web interfaces, which could be placed in a Sakai Web Content tool; however, that doesn't achieve any direct integration, such as creating an Assignment whose open date would be posted to the external scheduling software.

item.title: [REQ-28] Email Notification When Submitting High-Risk Items
item.description: Send a confirmation email when Sakai has successfully received a high-risk item. For instance, when a student submits an Assignment, they should get an email receipt that the system completed the process. The email can include an appropriate reference ID and time-stamps. This option could be configured to be system-wide, by site, or by student; a good default would be to have it on system-wide.
item.summary: Email Notification When Submitting High-Risk Items

comments.comment: Assigning to Luke for review.

Assignments, Tests & Quizzes (Samigo), and Gradebook currently store and display point-based assessment values in different maners. A recent discussion in the email thread in sakai- assessment@collab.sakaiproject.org called "Consistant grading (SAK-2848)" illustrated why this is a problem and had the above consensus. To see the majority of this thread/discussion please see the attached file (above) consistentGradingTread.rtf. ----------------------------- Original Description: Assignments, Tests & Quizzes (Samigo), and Gradebook currently store and display point-based assessment values in different maners. The recent discussion in the email thread in the "Sakai DG: Assessment Tools" illustrates why this is important and suggests appropriate resolutions. Exisiting assessment tools and any new related tools should conform as best as possible to a standard approach to point-based storage and display. In particular, the developing consensus for storing point-based assessments values appears to be doubles. By storing with as much percision as possible, then round-off errors are less likely to generate confusion for students and instructors. For the display of points, the developing consensus is for two decimal places. This will help also help reduce confusion related to round-off errors. For example, 0.33 or 0.67 perhaps more clearly indicate you received one-third or two-thirds of a point, respectively, on an assessment item. A desire for configuring the number of decimal places, at the system-wide and/or site-wide levels, has also been expressed; as has the desire not to allow such configuration.
Ready for voting
The comment dated "24-Feb-2006 16:18" was entered by mistake. It is not pertinent to this issue.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-29] Option to Enforce Unique Site Titles
item.description:
It would be nice to have support for enforcing unique site titles, currently Sakai allows one to have multiple sites with the same title, which can lead to confusion. (There are Sakai installations that are interested in multiple sites with the same title, so this could be implemented as an option.)

Use Cases:

* Instructors often teach the same course over and over. If their course site doesn't have a title with temporal information, such as GS-440 versus GS-440-F06, then it becomes confusing as to which site is which after a couple semesters of teaching the same course. (Instructors don't necessarily always want to delete old sites either, as it may have material from students they wish to reference, or their university may require that keep old student material on-hand for a certain time period.)

* Members of ad-hoc groups, such as project sites, which aren't uniquely named can also be confused as to which site is which. For instance, someone might be end up in multiple "Study Group" or "Lab Group" sites.

* Folks searching for sites on the Gateway or trying to join sites in the Membership tool also have problems telling which site is which when the name is the same. (Some help is provided if the Term field is used in the Gateway for course sites but not project sites, and in the Membership tool the Description is displayed, but only if it is simple text.)
item.summary: Option to Enforce Unique Site Titles

comments.comment: From REQ-164 by Chris Brandt: Once you have several years worth of terms for old course worksites, it will be difficult to determine which is the appropriate one to join from the memebership tool unless the term and year are part of the site label. Adding a colum to the display of Joinable worksites which shows the term (if applicable) would be a valuable addition. This wouldn't necessarily be usable by insitutions that have completely closed courses, but those with OCW initiatives such as MIT, or those who allow all site members access to all sites (such as UCD SVM) would benefit.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-30] Join Site by Requesting Membership
item.description:
Add the additional option for sites to be joinable only by request. In otherwords, a user could browse the list of joinable sites, but instead of being able to join immediately, they would have to go through some soft of approval process. For instance, they could click on a link next to a site in the Membership tool that would provide them with a little form to fill out, whichi would then generate an email to the site owner(s), who could then click on a link in the email to accept or deny the join request (and maybe add a comment to the automate message and instructions), which in turn would generate an appropriate email back to the requestor.

Use Cases:

* A project site where you don't know right away who all will be joining the site, but you don't want it to be wide-open for anyone to join. Receiving a request to join from someone would be a good enough threshold for them to have to cross to get in.

* A site might have some pre-requisite for joining that can be validated through the join request.

* A site you want to control access to, but not have to rely on Sakai administrators or out-of-band email requests to handle.
item.summary: Join Site by Requesting Membership

comments.comment: Reviewed by "Worksite & Admin Tools"

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-31] Offline component for learners to study while not connected to the internet
item.description:
One of the factors hindering the implementation of e-learning in Africa (and South Africa) is limited and expensive Internet connections. Low bandwidth remains an issue and prevents the delivery of rich media to learners. An alternative to increasing bandwidth to cater for this problem is the dissemination of learning content from a central server during off-peak hours. Internet connections can be used to keep learning content up to date on the remote computers. Because content can be downloaded once and studied without the need to remain on-line for extended periods costs can be greatly reduced for the learners. The learner can however still connect to the central server for learning activities such as discussion groups, reading of announcements etc.

What is needed is an intelligent off-line client that can update content from time to time as is needed. This client will provide the learner with most (all?) of the same functionalities as he/she will find on-line.
item.summary: Offline component for learners to study while not connected to the internet

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-32] Shift Site's Dated Material Forward for Re-Use in Future Semesters
item.description: In order to re-use a site in future semesters, whether by editing it or duplicating it, one of the big tasks is updating all the timed-related content. For instance, while the content of Assignments may remain mostly unchanged from semester to semester, the timing of their delivery, due dates, closing, etc., is always going to be different. Another example would be events in Schedule which represent the course's meeting times, and perhaps contain links to the appropriate lecture notes for each particular time. It would be nice to have a way to bulk move such time-dependent content forward for a new semester. For instance, it would be nice to be able to specify a new "first day" for a course, and have all the Schedule events moved relative to the difference with the old firest day; taking into account, of course, the differences such as university-wide off-days defined in a system-wide calendar.
item.summary: Shift Site's Dated Material Forward for Re-Use in Future Semesters

comments.comment: Can a feature like this be managed easily in practice? One challenge is that fall semesters often have less weeks than spring semesters. How would the algorithm accomodate this and how would it be presented to the end user? Would the algorthm account for this expansion or contraction in semester durations? Would it simply move every due date forward a specified number of days (accounting for semester specific holidays) or would it move it forward in proportion to the length of the semester?

Good questions. In our case, even though the total number of weeks varies between semesters, the actual number of class sessions generally stays the same. If there is one or two more or less class sessions, then it would still be nice just to move it all forward and then fine-tune the few sessions you need to in order to accommodate the differences. As to an algorithm, one way would be for Sakai to be aware of when class sessions occur and to think of Schedule events not only in terms of when they occur temporally, but also which ordinal class session they are of the semester (1st, 2nd, 3rd, ...). So, when I create a course site, it would pre-populate the Schedule with appopriate events (e.g., Lecture, Discussion, Lab) based on when my course meets. I could then attach appropriate materials to each meeting, such as my PowerPoint slides for each lecture event. If I decide to cancel a regular scheduled class, such as the day right before a major vacation break, then I would delete that paricular event from the Schedule; or, if I need to stick in a make-up session, I could insert that into the Schedule. (And it would be real nice if I could then slide the remaining class sessions around, if needed, if I made the deletion or addition after the semester started.) The next time I teach the course then, I could choose to migrate that information forward, perhaps with a UI something like a table that lists out my class sessions from the previous semester in one columne and matches them up with the class sessions in the current semester. I could then go trough and delete or insert class sessions here and there, if necessary, to get things to copy over to the dates I want; and, if possible, drag-and-drop sessions to change to order, if I decide to teach differently :) But I deviate here into design, the goal is to make re-use and re-scheduling of past material to a new semester as easy as possible.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-37] Sakai Saving State - Moving between tools and within pages of a tool should behave conistently for users.
item.description:
User need a consistent model for what will happen when they "go someplace else" within Sakai.

Currently, when you move between tools sometimes the tool the user left remains in the same state so when the user returns, they are dropped in the middle of a tool. For other tools, the tool resets itself when a user leaves it so when the return to the tool they arrive at the main page.

There is similar inconsistency with navigating within a tool. Sometimes, moving away from a page (but staying within the tool) saves the users data on page (a form for instance) until they come back. And in other tools, if the user moves away from a page without saving, the data will not be saved and the next time they visit that page it will be refreshed.

Original requirement below before combining this one with another:

Currently Sakai saves the state of a tool when you navigate away from it. For instance, if you are part way through creating a Resource and you click on the Schedule, when you come back to Resources, you'll find yourself right where you left off creating a new Resource, which can lead to confusion if you do not want to resume the process, are looking to do something different in Resources now, and are not familiar with the reset button for tools. Another approach is to reset a tool, and not save its state, when you navigate away from it, which means when you come back, if you want to resume your process, then you've lost everything you've done up to that part and have to start over. (Some other aspects of Sakai's behavior, which may compound the problems experienced here, include lack of support for the browser's back button and the percieved expectation that clicking on a tool in the left-hand menu, when already viewing the tool, should reset the tool, as opposed to learning about the little reset-icon in the top-left of the tool.)


There has always been a lot of debate over which model to adopt. The choice of saving state or not should be a system-wide configuration option.
item.summary: Sakai Saving State - Moving between tools and within pages of a tool should behave conistently for users.

comments.comment: Updated description for clarity and combined language from a requirement I had added that really included this issue with another one. I removed the saving state language from the other. UI group done with this one.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-39] Hotlink Items in Synoptic Views
item.description: When a tool provides a Synoptic View of its contents then the synopsized items should be linked to their full view. For example, clicking on a synopsized announcement on a site's Home should take you to the full view of that item in the Announcement tool.
item.summary: Hotlink Items in Synoptic Views

comments.comment: When I click the hotlink under specific, synopsized announcements, I do get brought to a full view. Granted, it does not bring me to the Announcement tool - is that what you're really after here?

Yep, the original request was that links take you to the full view of the item inside that item's tool. The goal of sending the user to the item view in the tool is to place them in the appropriate context for interacting with the item. In the case of Announcements, most folks are only going to be able to read it, so there isn't much interaction left for them to do, other than navigate to the next announcement. For other tools, however, such as Discusssion, they may want to reply to the item. Announcements is currently the only tool synopsis which currently contains links, so part of this requirement is also for all synopsis views to contain links.
I am linking this as relates to REQ-39 which asks for a link in the synoptic view into the content within the tool itself. This might be looked at in a review of the functionality of the Home tool.
Not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
Removing profile as a Component for this requirement.

Linked to "tools need sections" but didn't close the requirement.
Added link to "tools need sections" but did not close the requirement.
Linked to "tools need sections" but did not close the requirement.

"Section awareness" brings user-interface overhead as well as programming work, and making section-filtering visible within an already complex tool may make it unusable. For many tools, it might be more efficient to think of section awareness at the _site management_ layer. Given a way to create a sub-site (a folder within a site), the site administrator or instructor might give only certain sections access to that sub-site. Or might give section-specific access to an individual page or tool; e.g., the "Lab 2 Wiki" tool instance. The framework could then handle authorization checks before passing requests through to the tool code, and the tool code (and tool UI) wouldn't have to change at all. Confluence is a good example of how this might work. (Yes, I know that Confluence could be thought of as just a big, big wiki, but it's big enough to include its own administrative tools for subsite setup and user/group management.)
This issue is related to req-40, but the functionality described is specific enough that I don't think we should close the issue.

I think the "New Tool" componenet should be used to refer to specific tools that have not been created yeat, not to possible new tools that may be created. This is not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component

item.description:
Currently the "Preferences" tool appears only once for each user, in that user's "My Workspace". Preferences for email notification of changes are set there and apply to all worksites.

item.description:
A refinement of current admin tools, both UI and functionality. An admin tool that will list users and display courses or list courses and display users associated with course.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-51] Admin Copy Tool
item.description:
An admin tool that will copy a course or a site for Faculty not Admins thus freeing up admins for this function. Faculty will still want to copy courses or sites even with the WebDav respository. The batch import/export tool does not allow instructors or site maintainers to target specific areas.

The copy tool for instructors should do the following:
- identify the course/site to be copied
- identify the target to be copied to (new course, existing course)
- identify areas of the course to be copied allowing specific material or areas to be copied (includes assessments, images, etc.)
- will be able to copy user data (optional) if desired
item.summary: Admin Copy Tool

comments.comment: Jeshua, could you be more specific about the functionality you're looking for here? How do your needs compare to the existing Site Archive tool for admins? What does it do/not do that you are specifically interested in?

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-52] Merge Course/Site Tool
item.description:
An admin and instructor tool that will merge courses or sites into a target course, however, this tool is for instructors not admins. It would allow instructors to merge one course into another to allow teaching of several sections of courses within one sakai course.

The merge tool should do the following:
- identify the course/site to be the target or repository of the course sections
- identify or select the courses to be merged into the target course
- merge the enrollments into the target course for all roles (stdts, instructors, GTAs, etc) and data updates will automatically take effect within the target course
- this action (the merge) can be undone
- still identify students which were enrolled in the pre-merge sites

Use case:
Instructor A is teaching 2 courses that meet on different days. He would like to post all course materials, tests, etc... on one worksite. He would like to also be able to send announcements to all students, or just students in the class that meets on the first day. At the end of the semester, he will split the site back into the 2 original sites and post final exam information. When the classes are split, the course materials and data should be duplicated in both classes.
item.summary: Merge Course/Site Tool

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-54] Log Searching Tool
item.description:
An admin tool that will allow admins to check the logs in order to know when a person took a quiz, accessed an area, and what they did when they accessed said area.

The search should be able to be limited by users, sites, and dates. For example, I want to search the logs for the last week for site "Test site A" and user "student B" with a search term "quiz 4".

Use Case:
A student claims to have taken an online quiz 2 weeks ago but they have no grade in the gradebook. The admin (helpdesk support person) needs to be able to search the logs (through the interface) to see if there are any indications that the student took the quiz but the data was lost or removed.
item.summary: Log Searching Tool

item.title: [REQ-56] Use a Single "Name" to identifiy Resources
item.description:
A continuing source of confusion for users is the lack of correlation between the Title of a Resource and the ID by which the system knows the Resource. In general, users are expecting Resources to behave in a manner similar to their computers file system. Resources violates this by only looking at a Resource's system ID and ingoring the Title when a user performs actions which result in duplicate names. For example, users can end up with two or more Resources with identical Titles. The system knows the Resources are different because each was assigned a unique ID when it was uploaded, however, the user cannot necessarily tell from the UI what's going on. Also, they may attempt to upload a new version of a file using the same Title assuming that it will replace the old version; it does not, instead you end up with two identically named Resources.

A signle "name" or "ID" should be used to identify Resources for the purposes of listings, warning users about replacing an existing Resource during uploads, preventing more than one Resource having the same Title, etc.
item.summary: Use a Single "Name" to identifiy Resources

comments.comment: SAK-2250 provides another example of user-confusion resulting from multipe "names" for a Resource. In this case, the user replaces a Resource with a newly uploaded file having a different name (perhaps with a new date or revision number in the name) and the Resources Title doesn't change to reflect this, nor does its system ID for that matter.

SAK-2328 is another example of confusion resulting from the different references by which a Resource is known. In this case, the main point of confusion is that URL is not changing when a file is replaced with one of a different type, e.g., replace a PDF (.pdf) file with a Microsfot Word (.doc) file, even though the mime-type is correctly updated.

Another good example of the confusion: Comment by Diana Lee Perpich [31-Jan-2006 12:53] If I'm an instructor and I upload syllabus.doc on the first day of class, then two days later I replace it with an acrobat file, perhaps syllabus.pdf. The email notification that I can automatically send when I revise the resource will point to syllabus.doc which will download, but not open properly. Thus, defeating our purpose of a quick link.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-57] Google Indexing of Email Archives
item.description: Email Archive contents should be google indexable if site is public.
item.summary: Google Indexing of Email Archives

comments.comment: This would sure help folks trying to find stuff in the sakai-dev list.
Assigned to Maggie
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-59] Allow a user to disable email notifications
item.description:
We would like a setting in the preferences tool that allows a user to specify that no mails should be sent from the sakai system to his/her mail account.

There should also be an option to turn off this control at an institutional level (probably controled through sakai.properties) and to override it at a site level.

Use Case:
Student A is tired of getting email, they turn off their notifications. They should receive a series of warnings before they are allowed to turn it off that indicate they may miss important announcements. It should also indicate that the site owner can override the setting.
Use Case 2:
The instructor wants to send out a notification about class being cancelled. He knows that some students have turned off their notifications. He should be able to override the flag and send a notification that will reach all students.
Use Case 3:
Institution B wants to force students to always get notifications in Sakai. They turn on the notification globally and the control disappears. All settings are maintained and if the global flag is turned off, the users who turned off notifications will not get new messages.
item.summary: Allow a user to disable email notifications

comments.comment: When this is implemented, please keep in mind that some institutions may want to turn off the ability to block emails entirely. The original reason block didn't apply to high priority notifications was to allow instructors to be sure that an email was redeived by all participants, and that they couldn't subsequently claim that they never received the email. So allowing an institution to prevent the 'block all emails' control from showing up in the UI, or maybe allowing site owners to control whether in their site users can block emails would be useful.

It would be nice if the notifications could be turned off simply by clicking on a link in the footer of a recieved email rather than having to log back into Sakai to do it. A student may enroll in a course but then for whatever reason, stop attending after a few weeks. Sooner or later they forget their Sakai login but continue to recieve what to them is now spam. Having forgotten how to login to disable things, they're effectively condemned to recieve spam until the class ends. This isn't a hypothetical use case -- it happened to me when I subscribed to a umich course but only visited it once at the beginning of the semester and then promptly forgot my umich login.
Assigned to Maggie for review from the Collab and Communication perspective.
This is not a new tool, removed from "New Tool" component
Ready for voting.
Ready for voting. Has some similarities to REQ-64 though this relates to individual mail notification preferences vs. REQ-64 which focuses on worksite preferences.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-60] Redesign the resources tool to be more fdocument and student centered
item.description:
The resources tool, as it is right now is folder centred. This means I can categorise my documents in only one category. For instance if I make a folder for each course I'm in and one of my documents is essential for two or more courses I'll have to make a copy of the document for each folder it needs to be in. I would like Sakai to be document centred and to enable me to categorise/organise my documents in more than one way.

The resources tool is worksite centred. Sakai is about collaboration and collaboration in Sakai takes place in worksites. If I want to share my documents with other students and faculty the only way to do this is by starting or participating in a worksite. And I'll have to make a copy of the document for each worksite I want to publish it in. I would like Sakai to support ad hoc collaboration without the need to start a worksite and to enable me to share my documents without the need to copy them.

The OSP FX (functional requirements) group made a description of a resources tool that is more flexible and student centred, enabling collaboration in worksites and ad hoc collaboration. I would like this vision to be in the centre of Sakai. Mock-ups can be found at http://portfolios.itd.depaul.edu/ospi/Prototypes/OSPInterfacePrototypes.htm. Of special interest for this discussion are the links 'Manage a Collection' and 'Publish a portfolio'.
item.summary: Redesign the resources tool to be more fdocument and student centered

comments.comment: Jan: I believe this contains some of the same features as REQ-9. Could you confirm?

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.description:
Our interaction design requires that the name of the curent user is displayed on the screen. The purpose of this is to give the user a sense of 'mine' when they use sakai. This is different from the presence tool because only your own name would be displayed. We will be displaying this in the mast-head area of the page

This will be something that we are going to look into our selves. We hope other people share this requirement and that is can be made a part of Sakai.

This should also be able to be turned off globally using a flag in sakai.properties or something like that.
item.summary: Display the name of the current user in the site navigation

comments.comment: If a user is not logged into Sakai, then one might also use the same location to display a message indicating "not logged in" with a login link.
Added JSF and style guide as a component.

In most tools the permissions can be set to specify what users of each role can do with a tool. In some cases there can be roles for which a tool has no usefull purpose at all. It would be nice to be able to hide those tools or, even better, the page they are on from users of those roles.

Samples of tools that you may decide students don't need access to are:

Since most tools are on a separate page it would be preferable to be able to hide pages.

item.title: [REQ-63] Structured presentation of course content
item.description:
Course content must be presented to the students structured in a hierarchical way - similar to Windows explorer. See attached file for an example. We also need a way of importing course content into SAKAI from a standard (IMS).

Further, creation of this content from the SAKAI environment by lecturers. The lecturers see a similar screen, but have additional functionality for creating new topics. Topics can be created within topics. See attached file for an example.
item.summary: Structured presentation of course content

comments.comment: It would be ideal to have both SCORM and IMS-CP content import. Melete currently supports IMS-CP but only in a limited way (some schemas), and doesn't support depth of > 2 levels. Such support should be tested with offline structured content editors, including eXe (http://exelearning.org/)

item.title: [REQ-65] Email Archive should be deep-linkable/bookmarkable
item.description:
It is currently impossible to "link" to a message, because the tool state is (apparently) in the session.

The use cases are myriad, but for example:

A student asks "what were the requirements for the robot-building contest?". Another student replies with a link to the message in the email archive where the professor states the requirements. Currently that is impossible.

Even I as a sakai implementor would love to be able to send a link to (or bookmark) various sakai-dev emails. Currently one cannot do that.

At the very least (although it is really not totally sufficient either) the email could be handled like resources are, we there are "canonical" urls to retrieve them. Although really, the link should place the user in the context of the site and mail archive tool not just deliver the text of the message. However, currently there is no way to do that in Sakai in general, so maybe this is even a bigger requirement!

I am marking this as "Essential immediately" because, really the email archive tool is only useful for casual browsing without it. And really, given the slowness of the archive, it is not really useful for that either.
item.summary: Email Archive should be deep-linkable/bookmarkable

item.title: [REQ-70] Adminstratiors should be able to view a user's profile data
item.description:
The personal data which is edited and displayed by the "Profile" tool is more extensive than the data which is edited and displayed by the "Users" tool. However, the only way to see "Profile" data for a user other than oneself is via the "Roster" tool on a particular site. Administrators have no way to access it. Since the Profile data is system-wide, there should be a system-wide way to see it.

(Behind the scenes, the "Users" and "Account" tools access legacy user data whereas the "Roster" and "Profile" tools access newer core services for EduPerson-style data.)

One way to approach this would be to add "Profile" links in the administrative "Users" tool. Another way would be to implement a replacement for the legacy "Users" tool which takes advantage of the newer data and provides more services.

Use Cases:

* The system administrator sees that a user has been causing dozens of crashes over the past two days. There's no response from the user's email account. The admin goes to the user's profile to find their phone number, department, and possible IM information.
item.summary: Adminstratiors should be able to view a user's profile data

comments.comment: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-71] Adminstrators should be able to block user login
item.description:
Adminstrators should be able to disable a user's access to Sakai. Deleting a user's local record within Sakai isn't sufficient given the possibility of an external user directory provider being used to identify the user during login.

As originally described, this requirement might be met by simply blocking login attempts and giving the usual "invalid login" alert.

REQ-97 describes a similar requirement, except for user access to a particular site rather than to all of a Sakai installation. It includes the ability to give the "banned" user a message explaining what's happened, which might be useful here as well.

Use Cases:

* An employee has been terminated but is still included in the local LDAP directory. Access to Sakai resources and applications must be immediately revoked.

* A student appears to be using their local workspace to store and share illegal material. The student's access should be blocked pending an investigation.
item.summary: Adminstrators should be able to block user login

comments.comment: Feliz, you write that this can be useful "for several reasons". Can you describe a few of those reasons? One reason I ask is the existence of REQ-97 , which specifies disabling user access on a site by site basis, and optionally displaying a message explaining the reason for blocking access. I'm wondering what use cases that wouldn't cover.
I've guessed at some use cases, but the original reporter may have others to add. Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-72] be able to specify site quotas on a user, user type, or site basis

it should be possible to specify quotas to My Workspaces and Sites on a User Type, and Site Type basis using the admin
interface (something like working with realms).
item.summary: be able to specify site quotas on a user, user type, or site basis

comments.comment: Currently there is a loophole in the quota management capabilities, which is that if a user exceeds her quota in My Workspace, she can simply create another X personal project sites, each with it's own quota. A per-user quota would close this loophole.
This seems like a global issue.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-73] Sakai installations need more flexibility in time format
item.description:
Currently, Sakai applications display time in an AM/PM format. This convention is best known in the United States and Canada, and can be confusing to users who are accustomed to a 0-23 hour format. The time format needs to to be settable system-wide. Another possibility is to let it be set by user preferences, or via the locale setting in the user's browser.

Use Cases:

* All of the users at an installation at a Portuguese university are used to the 24 hour clock. When installing Sakai, the adminstrators choose to default to Portuguese language conventions. Users who log in with a browser set to a European locale or left at the default will see times expressed as a 24-hour clock rather than an 12-hour clock.

Related Functional Requests and Bugs include:

SAK-3823
SAK-3829
SAK-3830
item.summary: Sakai installations need more flexibility in time format

comments.comment: Feliz, would your requirement be met by full support for date/time localization, as described in SAK-3823 ?
I modified the target components list to "Global" and "UI", since the user preferences tool probably won't be the most likely spot for the work.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-74] Ad-Hoc Group Management
item.description:
As with sectioning, the full implications are bigger than a single tool, but this place is as good as any.

Instructors need to be able to create ad-hoc groups and *group spaces* (group collaboration areas), and they need to be able to manage these within their course sites.

Use Cases:
- An instructor or TA creates an ad-hoc group of a subset of site users. Following creation group membership can be adjusted.
- Each group has their own collaboration space which includes the usual collaboration tools.
- Since students may typically spend more time in a group space than a course space, the group site should not require navigation through the course site.
- An instructor has an option to import groups from another site (i.e. groups may span multiple sites)
- An instructor or TA wants to send emails/messages/announcements to specific groups, and not have to remember an email address for each group.
- Assignments and the gradebook should be "group-aware" to the extent that group projects may be submitted for grading, and feedback may be received on either an individual or group basis.
item.summary: Ad-Hoc Group Management

comments.comment: This kind of functionality also rose to the top of the UC Berkeley requirements list. We haven't had a a chance to think it through at the use case level but Clay's list is a great start. For us the general idea is that Sakai support group work in the classroom. For this to be a useful tool it should be integrated across tools where it makes sense (e.g. after the group is created instructors can send an announcement to the group, create assignments for the group, a dropbox gets created for the group, etc.) In addition, since instructor and students needs and goals are different for group work and section management, they will have different requirements and workflows. I'm adding this comment since there was previous talk in the community that these 2 were virtually the same...just differenly named types of groups.
I would like to add to this the ability to create groups automatically in more flexible ways: for example by randomly assigning students to groups.
Seems to be related to more flexible groups.

item.title: [REQ-76] Numerical Final Grades
item.description: The current gradebook only allows letter grades for its final reports. It seems to be based on the assumption that the gradebooks reports should somehow be "official" (or as close to official as possible) grade reports. Faculty often however just want to get an Excel export of the final numbers, and they'll fiddle with the final grades more subjectively later. There should be an option to have numerical final grades, even for the export.
item.summary: Numerical Final Grades

comments.comment: Assigning to Luke for review.
Ready for voting

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)
