item.title: [REQ-82] Contact/Help tool that records user state
item.description:
An online help form that captures the user system info as well as the referring URL or siteID.
- referring URL or site ID
- Platform and OS
- connection or ISP
- Browser and version
- username
- firewall info
- description of problem/issue/question

Ideally, this form would capture information about what tool the user is currently in, what site they are in, any information that can be pulled from the browser about their system, and anything that might help troubleshoot the problem they are having.

The email address where the help request is sent should be configurable.

Use Case:
A user encounters a problem while using sakai. They click on the "request assistance" link at the top (or some other name) and a pop up window appears. The window contains information about the user and what they were doing before they clicked on the help link. They fill in a description of their problem or question and then click a button to send this to a helpdesk email address.
item.summary: Contact/Help tool that records user state

item.title: [REQ-86] The Drop Box tool should work better with course sections
item.description:
The Drop Box should be changed to give instructors and TAs assigned to individual sections an easier and more organized way to work with students in sections.

The original requirement description suggested creating Drop Box section folders. When an instructor creates sections in his course site, a Drop Box folder hierarchy would be based on those sections.

There are some possible issues with that approach, however.

1) A student can be in more than one section, which means the Drop Box would appear multiple times.
2) Because the Drop Box and Resource "Title" sorts only happen within folders, it would become impossible for the instructor to quickly access the drop box for a single student without also knowing what sections the student was in.
3) A TA still sees all the drop boxes for students who aren't in the TA's assigned sections.

A different approach to making the Drop Box section aware would be to support filtering by section name (e.g., with a drop-down menu showing the names of all sections that the instructor or TA has access to) and only show TAs sections which are assigned to them.

Use Cases:

* An instructor creates Lab 1 and Lab 2 sections. The course site's Drop Box then displays the following folder tree:

folder SMPL 001 001 W06 dropbox
        subfolder Lab 1
               subfolder Bob Jones
               subfolder Ann Smith
         subfolder Lab 2
               subfolder Joe Jackson
               subfolder Kate Klein

* An instructor goes to the Drop Box and sees folders for all students. To focus on the students in Lab 2, she selects "Lab 2" from the sections menu.

* A TA who is assigned to the Lab 2 section goes to the Drop Box and sees folders only for students in the Lab 2 section.
item.summary: The Drop Box tool should work better with course sections

comments.comment: Kim, I've revised your description pretty heavily. Could you take a look and make sure that your original intentions haven't been lost?
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-93] Configure Order of Items in Worksite's Lefthand Menu
item.description:
The worksite instructor or maintainer should be able to re-order the worksite menu items, or the worksite's left-hand menu or toolbar, depending on what you like to call it. For example, if the instructor wants their course's menu to be ordered "Announcements, Dropbox, Discussion, Schedule, Assignments" they will be able to rearrange the order to fit that need.

Use Cases:

-instructors & maintainers have control over the "flow" of their course and are not restrained by the global menu properties

-worksites can have more variety in their appearance

-one could place the most commonly accessed tools in a worksite near the top

-tool order should start in a uniform order, such as alphabetical (REQ-324)
item.summary: Configure Order of Items in Worksite's Lefthand Menu

comments.comment: Keeping a uniform order, however, would probably make it easier for folks working with multiple sites. For instance, students taking four or five courses would probably appreciate the tools always occuring in the same order -- even if there are differences in the tool-sets used -- in all their courses; having the Resource tool in the same general place each time means they can get to it more easily.

I'd have to agree with Kim on this one. In 7+ years working with online learning, I've never heard of a student requesting the tools in a particular order. However, I've definitely had faculty members requesting this both with WebCT and Sakai. I guess, a new ticket could be created that requests the ability for any user to change the order of the menu items. This might solve the problem.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-94] Change the default name of "Tests & Quizzes" to "Assessments"
item.description:
There is a desire to change the _default_ name of SAMigo* from "Tests and Quizzes" to "Assessments" in the tool registration configuration file.

The main rationale for this name change is that SAMigo is often used for more generic assessment purposes in non-course sites like surveys. While the default name for any tool can be configured within Sakai, the gravity of a default name can be substantial (there is power in words :) and it is probably better when a default name meets the most, likely uses cases.

A little history on the name "Tests & Quizzes", so that it doesn't seem so arbitrary to detractors: before SAMigo was introduced into Sakai 1.5 it had been assumed that SAMigo would be called "Assessments". However, there was desire from some core schools to better distinguish its name and purpose from the existing "Assignments" tool, so it was "Tests & Quizzes" was adopted to better accomodate that desire.

* For those who might not know the history of the name "Samigo", this the code/project name of what was originally intended to be the Sakai Assessment Manager (SAM). When it was discovered that a proprietary software already existed, (possibly Significance Analysis of Microarrays http://www-stat.stanford.edu/~tibs/SAM/) another name had to be coined.

Well, since the SAM project was the child of the Navigo project: SAM + igo = SAMigo ;)
item.summary: Change the default name of "Tests & Quizzes" to "Assessments"

comments.comment: I was actually just thinking abou this the other day and wishing it was called Assessments. ;)
At IU, we have renamed the tool to "Tests and Surveys" because "Tests and Quizzes" seemed to be a little redundant.

We'd like the default name to be different things in different sites. It would be ideal if the tool registration file could specify site-type-specific names, e.g. in course sites we'd call it Assessments, and in project sites we'd call it Surveys. Samigo itself needs some tweaking to work well for Surveys, but that's another Requirement :-)

I have been an advocate for this tool to have a different name, but I believe "assessments" is not a good replacement name. Please consider: 1. As a Collaboration and Learning Environment, many of us are deploying Sakai to support research, committees, and other activities that are not related to teaching and learning. SAMigo can be used to administer research surveys, but that important use will not be obvious in "worksites" if the tool name suggests a teaching purpose. 2. The term "assessment" has many, many different meanings. Some associate this term with ePortfolios while others see it as related to assignments. There are many views,and this name may just shift the confusion to a different area. For there reasons, I don't believe the Current or proposed name are the best choice for a CLE. We deployed with a name of "Tests and Surveys" to meet #1. I am pleased to see this discussion. -Brad

I would go further than Stephen and say we would like to see the tool interface reflect a survey purpose in worksites and an assessment purpose in course sites. This should allow some simplification of the interface according to context specific purposes. That said, if the only offer on the table is a change to the name, I'm more inclined to go with Indiana's 'tests and surveys'.

I'd also like to see the default tool name changed. Tests and Quizzes doesn't capture surveying functionality, nor does it capture the tool's potential use for online tutorials or simulations. We downplay TESTS in our own online environment and talk about quizzes. Tests seem to come with particular expectations that are difficult to meet with any online tool. Instructors want to somehow block students from using the internet while testing, to block them from any chance to save or print what they see on the screen, to stop them from simutaniously using email or IM, to never time students out, and to be utterly unsusceptible to network failure. Instructors do administer high-stakes tests in our current environment, but I believe they do so with the knowledge that a web-based testing comes with certain substantial caveats. So, while I like the concreteness of Tests & Surveys, I am afraid of Tests. I suspect Quizzes & Surveys isn't accurate for schools that intend to use the tool for high-risk testing. Besides, I find that people don't always think of surveys and ballots the same way-- and that's another use that appears to be on the rise. That leaves me in the Assessment camp (even though I sympathize with Brad's comments about ePortfolio). In my experience, our researchers and staff haven't balked at the use of assessments as a teaching-only term. Finally, I'd like to add to the discussion the notion that terms throughout the tool may need to be reassessed. With so many non-teaching uses of our own local tool, we have replaced Instructor and student with Manager and Respondent. I apologize that I haven't looked carefully at recent nightly builds, but I'm guessing that instructor and student show up hard-coded.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-95] Percentage based grading
item.description:
Allow instructors to set up their gradebooks based on percent weighted assigments, rather than (or as an alternative to) the current point-weighted assignments method.

Real life example from management class syllabus:

Students will be graded according the follwing formula:
    Organization project report: 35%
    Issue project report 35%
    Student project presentation: 15%
    Student overall Class participation: 15%

(end of example)

In the current GB the instructor would enter the numbers as points rather than percentages, but would then need to grade reports as a number between 0 and 35. In a percentage based system an instructor would grade all of the assignments from 0-100. The gradebook shoud then do the calculations based on the weights given.

This is the grading method that predominates at MIT.
item.summary: Percentage based grading

comments.comment: Weighted column needs can be catered to through formula (a.k.a "calculated") columns.
Assigning to Luke for review.
reassigning to myself to relieve Luke of some work.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-96] Users should be able to change their username and retain access to user data saved under the old username
item.description:
When a user changes his username, the user no longer has access to data saved under the old username. Presently, this is a problem that is not easily solved because Sakai associates user data with the user's username. Therefore, to associate the data with a new username, the username would need to be changed for every tool that stores user data. Some of this data is stored in xml blobs, which is not easily accessible. To resolve this problem, Sakai can associate the user data with a randomly generated ID that is unique to the user rather than the user's username. This ID would be related to the user's username, which would allow the user's username to be changed in one table.

Requirements:
Sakai can associate user data with a randomly generated ID that is unique to the user
Sakai can associate the randomly generated ID with the user's username
Sakai administrators can change a user's username
User can still retain access to user data saved under the old username when logged in with the new username
item.summary: Users should be able to change their username and retain access to user data saved under the old username

comments.comment: Linked to requirement that would let instructors or administrators rename users.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-97] Instructors should be able to disable a user's access to a site without removing the user from the site
item.description:
An instructor may wish to disable a student's access to a site for an indefinite period of time because the student has not been participating as expected. It is possible to remove a student from a site when the student has been explicitly added as a site participant. However, for universities which integrate site memberships with official course registrations, the student might be re-added automatically.

Use Cases:

* A student has been disruptive in a course site and needs to be blocked from the site. However, while the student remains on the official class roster, he continues to show up as a participant in the site. The instructor disables the student's access to the site without removing the student, and writes a message to explain why. When the student logs in and attempts to access the course site, he sees the message indicating why his access has been disabled.

* After meeting with the disruptive student, the instructor re-enables the student's access to the course site.
item.summary: Instructors should be able to disable a user's access to a site without removing the user from the site

comments.comment: Because this effects authorization and site access from the portal, I've added the "Sakai Application Framework" as a component.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-99] Users should be able to restrict access to their profile information
item.description:
Users should be able to restrict access to their public and/or personal information to site members in a specific role.

Use Cases:

* A student wants instructors in his course sites to have access to his personal information (e.g., email address, phone number). He does not want other students to have access to this information, but he doesn't mind if they have access to his public information (e.g., name, major).

* An instructor shares her Profile with students enrolled in her courses, but not with the student population as a whole.
item.summary: Users should be able to restrict access to their profile information

comments.comment: Another restriction might be that as an instructor, I would like to share my info with students enrolled in my course, but not the student population as a whole.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-101] Instructor should be able to make schedule items available to the general public
item.description:
Requirements:
Instuctor can make a schedule item available to the general public
Sakai can display a schedule item to the general public that an instructor has made available

<example>
Perhaps an instructor would like his/her course materials, such as the schedule item to be available to students who may be thinking about taking her class in the future. By making the schedule items available to the general public, future students would have the chance to review them to determine if this class is the right fit for him.
</example>
item.summary: Instructor should be able to make schedule items available to the general public

comments.comment: Ready for Vote.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-102] More flexible person names must be supported by Sakai
item.description:
In Sakai's legacy user services, there are only two name fields for a person: "first name" and "last name". However, proper name ordering varies widely across cultures, and more name fields may be needed to support proper ordering.

Sakai applications typically show names in two ways.

1) As a greeting or other full name display. (This is LDAP's "cname" or "common name".) In English and most other European languages, the format is "GivenName [SecondGivenName] FamilyName". In Chinese, Hungarian, and Korean cultures, the format is "FamilyName GivenName".

2) As a sorting field. (For example, in a gradebook's list of students.) For an English name, the format would be "FamilyName, GivenName"; for a Chinese name, "FamilyName GivenName".

With middle names (AKA second given name), prepositions (AKA link names, or family name prefixes), and relationships (e.g., "Jr.", "III", "fils"), the rules across cultures become even more complicated.

Sakai needs to be able to properly display common-names and sorting-names for its users. Specifically, this requirement was entered to support Dutch names.

Use Cases:

* A Dutch name such as "Victor van Dijk" needs to be alphabetized as "Dijk, Victor van".

* A French name such as "Aimee de L'Aigle" needs to be alphabetized as "L'Aigle, Aimee de".

* A Chinese name such as "Wong Kar-Wai" needs to be alphabetized as "Wong Kar-Wai".

* A Welsh name such as "John Fitz Gerald" needs to be alphabetized as "Fitz Gerald, John".

Technical notes:

The Dutch and French cases above could be taken care of by adding a field to the existing Sakai user tables and forms. (A less user-friendly workaround with the current DB might be to put prepositional prefixes such as "van der" and "de" in the existing "first name" field.)

If required, the Chinese case could be taken care of by adding system-wide properties to configure the ordering of given and family names. However, this assumes that all users at a site follow the same naming conventions, which may not be true for all installations.

The distinction between "middle name" and "prepositional prefix" becomes more important when an honorific combines with the family name. For a Dutch name, it should be "Mr. Van Dijk" rather than "Mr. Dijk". In that case, it again becomes necessary to configure the orderings.

A simple approach used by some systems is to store "common name" and "sorting name" directly as separate fields.
item.summary: More flexible person names must be supported by Sakai

comments.comment: Victor, would using Middlename as you've described be a complete solution for Ducth names? Or, is just a best practice you've come to as a result of restrictive systems? For instance, I have a relative known as Peter Andrew von Knoop, where Andrew is truly a middlename (at least in the sense I'm used to in North America), but the von is something else. I've seen some systems that handle van, von, etc., as a "linkname" and separate from firstname, middlename, and lastname. In your example, it sounds like in this case alphabetization would follow: [lastname], [firstname] [middlename] [linkname]

Peter, I wondered if I'd used the appropiate terminology. To use your example "Andrew" would be a 'second firstname' in Dutch and is only used with official cases like printed names on a degrees. The firstname is for daily usage and middlenames are not. Firstname is in this example the name that's being used by friends, co-workers etc. Like Peter in your example, if Peter is used by his surroundings. Alphabetization would be: [ lastname], [firstname] [linkname] -> 'Knoop, Peter van'

Good, it sounds like we can kept this simple then: we can get by with supporting first, middle, and last names (unless someone else has use case otherwise?), and that the jist of the matter is to introduce configurable sorting in Sakai. Here in the US the need is for [middle=van] [last=Knoop], [first=Peter], wheres in Holland (and eslewhere?) one needs [last=Knoop], [first=Peter] [middle=van].
Good! Excellent! That's what I was thinking. There is one more thing. If I look at the 'SAKAI_USER' table the column 'MIDDLE_NAME' needs to be added.

Name ordering issues like this are why we've been distinguishing between "sort name" and "display name" (equivalent to "greeting name") in our person-data service facades. (Another example: Chinese names which are ordered the same in both cases.) This is the sort of decision that should be handled framework-wide rather than leaving it up to the savvy of every application developer. Behind the framework service scences, configurable sorting of FIRST_NAME, MIDDLE_NAME, LAST_NAME for each usage sounds like a good implementation approach. I wonder if there are any existing Java libraries to handle this aspect of internationalization....

The "salutation" use case ("Hello, Mr. Van Dijk") needsthe distinction between a "middle name" (= second given name) and a "link name", since Americans wouldn't say "Hello, Mr. Allen Poe". Luckily, I don't think any Sakai applications are that polite yet!
I added some components to make the extent of the requirement clearer.

Victor, as a temporary workaround until more flexible name support is available, could you handle your problem by putting "Victor van" in the first-name field and "Dijk" in the last-name field? It's counter-intuitive, but it seems as if it would end up generating the right alphabetization.

I tried to formalize the requirement but may have overgeneralized it. Here's Victor Maijer's original description: In Dutch and other languages the use of 'Middlenames' is quite important and is being used different depending on the situation. An example: We have someone called 'Victor van Dijk' The name could be defined as: FIRSTNAME = 'Victor' MIDDLENAME = 'van' LASTNAME = 'Dijk' Usage of this name would be as follows: If you greet someone it would be: 'Hello [FIRSTNAME] [MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME]' -> 'Hello Victor van Dijk' or 'Hello Mr. [MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME] -> 'Hello Mr. Van Dijk' (mind the use of the capitol 'V') When we alphabetize, a list of students in a gradebook for example, it would be: [LASTNAME], [FIRSTNAME] [MIDDLENAME]-> 'Dijk, Victor van' and NOT(!) like [MIDDLENAME] [LASTNAME], [FIRSTNAME] -> 'Van Dijk, Victor' This last example is how Blackboard handles 'Middlenames' and is the reason why out first instructors are walking away from Blackboard. It is not doable for them to administrate 300 students in a gradebook with faulty alphabetization.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

Thanks Ray for working this out! Your proposed workaround to put 'Victor van' in the first-name looks like a workable solution. I did a quick scan and it looks like either the 'user id' is used or the complete name (firstname lastname) is used.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-103] Sites browsing needs performance improvements, sorting, and direct links to public content
item.description:
The legacy tools which browse available sites (including "Worksite Setup" and the Gateway "Sites" tool which shows available sites to visitors) need several improvements.

1) Performance issues need to be taken care of. (Probably a redesign of some underlying services will be needed to achieve this, since the necessary data is currently spread among different tables.)

2) Sorting by "Term" must be supported for course sites. (Making this efficient may also require some service redesign, since the term is not currently exposed as a column in the database.)

3) Visitors should be given a direct link to the public content of a site, if such a page exists.

Use Cases:

* An instructor logs in, goes to Worksite Setup, and sorts sites by term in order to find course sites from last fall.

* A new student visits the institution's LMS to see what sort of Sociology classes are being offered. Without logging in, she's able to quickly see a list of this term's sites. She clicks on the "Public Page" link for one and gets an idea of what's being done there.
item.summary: Sites browsing needs performance improvements, sorting, and direct links to public content

comments.comment: Tied in with this is also the notion of a URL to the public content, so that a URL can be given out that gets users to the page that contains the list of public info.
John, do you have any information on what exactly the performance issues are an any suggested fixes at this point?

Glenn knows what the performance problems are. One is that term is a property rather than a column in the db, so it is expensive to do any sorts. I think the data displayed on that page comes from several different tables, so the joins when searching cause lots of perfomance problems.

John Leasia's original description: The current Sites tool (sakai.sitebrowser) has had performance issues such that we had to remove it from the UM installatiion. We need this tool back essentially as is but with a restructuring that eliminates performance problems it was causing. Included is the need in this tool as well as others (Worksite Setup for example) to be able to sort by Term when term is one of the columns in a list. Without the tool, there isn't a way for non authenticated users to get at content earmarked as public. There doesn't need to be any design as the tool exists and has been in use.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.
I have an old design that was partially implemented that includes a public view of a page and any public Resources or Announcements. Let me know if you'd like to see it.

item.title: [REQ-104] Selected course site sections should be automatically created and maintained based on external roster feeds
item.description:
Use Cases:

* An instructor creates a course site whose student membership comes from 3 Lecture sections of Psych 100. She chooses to automatically create and populate corresponding visible user groups in her site. Section aware tools then let her see which Lecture section a student is part of, and let her filter and assign students by Lecture section. As students are dropped from or added to the external feeds, they appear in or disappear from the appropriate site sections. The instructor can use Section Info to add internally managed students and TAs to the site sections.
item.summary: Selected course site sections should be automatically created and maintained based on external roster feeds

comments.comment: John Leasia's original description: Along with REQ-40 and REQ-74 which add group control to other tools, as an option it would be useful to allow auto creating groups from the roster for each class section that might be in a site via a provider id. For example, if a site contained 3 rosters because the provider id was 2006,3,A,PSYCH,100,[001,002,003] it would be nice to automatically create a group 001, 002, 003 with the associated rosters, and have those groups change as the enrollment in the given section changes due to drops/adds etc. Instructors could still add students manually to such groups.

This use case is a major driver for the Course Site Management project which is underway by the CM WG. So far, that project includes the following related requirements, not mentioned by John: - The instructor needs more (and more friendly) information about external courses and sections than just a single roster string. - Default site section names should be provided but can be overwritten. - If the roster feeds come from different courses, the course must be taken into account in the section names. - Reconciliation rules must be clearly defined to avoid conflicts between automatic and manual management of memberships. - It must be possible for instructors to take over internal management of a section without having to disband the section first.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.description: Each site, represented through its tab, should be able to be "undocked" into its own browser window and ?re-docked" back into the window it was launched from
item.summary: Undockable sites

This would allow easy addition of academic and school calendars to a Sakai worksite, or any other calendar that supports iCal. This could also be used to add class meeting times to class sites, and student schedules to My Workspace schedules.
item.summary: Calendar subscription capability

comments.comment: Pick a cal standard.
Added to 'Schedule' component.
Ready for vote.

item.title: [REQ-109] Search across site and sites
item.description: A Search capability is needed that allows searching through all content in a site, or through all content in all sites in which the user is a member.
item.summary: Search across site and sites

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-111] Resource Viewer Tool
item.description: The resources tool is cluttered because it has everything needed to create new resources and edit existing resources as well as giving hierarchical access to large resource collections. Lots of people want different views of resources. One common request is the ability to create a list of resources (and possibly other types of entities) related to a particular part of a course or subproject. If we make the resources tool more like that, we break the hierarchical view. Instead, we should make a new tool that is intended as a resource viewer. This tool would focus on making it easier for a site maintainer to create a simple list of resources and format it as they see fit. The list itself would be read-only.
item.summary: Resource Viewer Tool

comments.comment: A use case for this tool: An instructor wants to create an item in the "tool" menu (at the left side of the screen) labeled "Week 1" containing a list of resources relevant to the first week's lectures and readings for a course. The instructor adds a "ResourceViewer" tool to the site and names it "Week 1". The instructor then configures the tool. Because the instructor has maintainer permissions for the site, she sees a link labeled "Add" in the global menu for the tool. Clicking the "add" link brings up the resources attachment helper, allowing her to attach a link to any resource she has access to (in any site, if "see all sites" is enabled). It also allows her to create a new attachment. She can add multiple items if she chooses. The items do not have to be in the same folder in the resources tool. Clicking "finish" in the attachment helper returns the instructor to the ResourcesViewer. The item(s) she added are listed there. Next she can format the display. Maybe there's a "format" button in the tool's global menu. That allows her to pick what fields will be shown for each item in the list and maybe even relative font sizes. She can also define an order for the items in the list. The default order should be the order in which items were added to the list, but the maintainer has the ability to sort on any field and rearrange by moving items up or down in the list. The default view the instructor sees is the same simple view the students see. It's only when she clicks an action in the tool's global menu that she sees additional controls. Students see a simple flat list of resources (and maybe other types of entities such as discussion threads or assignments). They can click on items to access them. Clicking on a resource should access it through the access servlet. If we provide access to other entity types, we would want to launch them in the "viewer" for that entity type. For example, if there is a link to an assignment, clicking on the link for an assignment would take the student into the assignment tool.
Related to REQ-9. Maybe these are alternative descriptions for the same requirement(s)?

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-113] Accessibility--Title and Content Frames should be combined
item.description:
Separate title and content frames create a situation where tool headings are often redundant and navigation is cumbersome. For example, if a screen reader user has his JAWS settings on default, he will hear the following description:

Beginning of announcements title frame
Announcements title frame
Help
End of announcements title frame
Beginning of announcements content frame
Announcements content frame
Add
Merge
Options
Permissions
Announcements heading one
item.summary: Accessibility--Title and Content Frames should be combined

comments.comment: Reclassified as a portal issue.
Reclassified as a portal issue per discussion with Gonzalo Silverio.

This is a portal issue per Anthony and Gonzalo's comments. However, it is part of a larger issue on the use of iFrames in Sakai. As such, fixing this problem may involve significant changes to the Sakai UI strategy. Fixing this is further out than 2.2.

Is it really necessary to tie this to the larger issue of iFrames and Sakai UI strategy? My preference is to resolve this problem and then deal with the larger issues. Otherwise, I am concerned that this fix will continue to languish. BTW, I am no fan of iFrames, but this would significantly improve the experience for persons using screen readers. Let's move on this and settle the iFrames issue post 2.2.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-114] Anonymous poll tool
item.description:
A simple but useful tool is one which can quickly survey opinion on a specific topic - a poll tool.

The tool should provide a simple multiple-choice question, allowing respondents to choose one or possibly multiple options.

Aggregate results are immediately available to participants.

The poll tool should be optionally integrated with discussion (ideally targetted at Message Centre) so that it's possible to follow a link to a topic / thread about the poll. There may also be other integration points and features, e.g. ability to send an email notification of a new poll, or automatically add an announcement about the poll (with a link to take the poll and/or view results).

Some screenshots from an existing CMS illustrating the basic idea are attached.
item.summary: Anonymous poll tool

comments.comment: This seems like something that could be done using Samigo.

Maybe. But the overheads of using Samigo at present (in terms of complexity) are such that probably no-one would ever do so. So I think of this as squarely in the "new tool" arena, though it's possible that Samigo could be modified to have an ultra-simple mode for this application. The use case is quite different to assessments or formal surveys - these polls are for informally and quickly testing opinion or gathering simple results over a period of time.
Reassigning to the New Tools area per Stephen Marquard's comment.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-115] Online surveys and course evaluations
item.description:
There are 2 use cases for a tool which can be used for surveys:

1. Research and collaboration groups using Sakai who wish to survey participants or a broader sample of people online

2. Course evaluations

This capability is similar to that currently provided by T&Q, but with some important differences, e.g.:
- No correct answer
- No references to grading, assessment, etc.
- Support for presenting and exporting results in various ways

It is expected that the easiest way of achieving this would be to extend T&Q.

Expanded upon by Owen McGrath and edited slightly by Kristol Hancock:
In terms of the survey-ish uses cases (e.g., group collaboration, formative or summative course evaluation) there would seem to be an opportunity right away to improve the use interface by optionally hiding references to scores and scoring, as Stephen mentioned. I have also been wondering for a while if it might make more sense to liberate "survey" from being just a question type. It would make more sense to have "survey" as a general assessment type that allows for a wide range of questions types such as Short Answer/Essay, Fill-in-the-blank, and the scale type questions currently offered by the survey question type.
item.summary: Online surveys and course evaluations

comments.comment: For end of course evaluations a couple of features make for better turnout and easier management: 1) End of course evaluations should be enabled or disabled by a Sakai admin toward the end of the semester. 2) When the admin enables the feature the following occurs: -When the student logs in they are prompted to fill out end of course evals for specified courses ( the Sakai admin should be able to configure whether the student has to complete the evals before continuing into a course or whether they can click through ) -The prompts continue until the student has either finished all the evals or the Sakai admin disables the feature.

Another use case for surveys is in-class assessment; such as surveys using clicker or responder systems. Extending T&Q would fit nicely with that, as students can already be in Sakai taking their notes on the Power Point lecture slides posted for class and chatting with the teaching assisstants in class via Chat. Sometimes such assessment is done anonymously just to get a feel for where the class and instruction are at, and sometimes it is important to keep track of who filled out the survey so points can be awarded as a way to encourage (and take) attendence.

In terms of the survey-ish uses cases (e.g., group collaboration, formative or summative course evaluation) there would seem to be an opportunity right away to improve the use interface by optionally hiding references to scores and scoring, as Stephen mentioned. I have also been wondering for a while if it might make more sense to liberate "survey" from being a just question type. Would it make more sense to have "survey" as a general assessment type that allows for a wide range of questions types such as Short Answer/Essay, Fill-in-the-blank, and the scale type questions currently offered by the survey question type?

Owen, that is a good point and I believe is the mentality behind assigning 0 points to a question type such as short answer/essay or fill-in-the-blank. This way, an assessment author can make any question type a 'survey' question. However, I do agree with the need to have a 'survey' as a general assessment type. This would negate the need to assign 0 points to a question type.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-116] Users should be given a way to log in and reset lost passwords
item.description:
When user accounts are explictly added to Sakai, the new user will receive an email with their password. However if a user loses his/her password, there is no way for the user to recover a password (e.g. by having a new one emailed to them).

This is an important capability which needs to be in core Sakai. Otherwise it creates significant support issues as the guest userbase grows.

Use Cases:

* A visiting scholar will be contibuting content to a project site from her own institution. A Sakai user account is added for her based on her email address, and she's added to the site. A month later, she's ready to contribute but no longer remembers her password. After failing to log on, she clicks on a "Forgot Password?" link. After verifying a password reset, she's then emailed instructions for logging in, with the understanding that she must immediately change her password after logging in.

Solutions separately implemented by Rutgers and UNISA are described in the comments.
item.summary: Users should be given a way to log in and reset lost passwords

comments.comment: Stephan, could you describe how the Rutgers and UNISA solutions work from the user perspective?

There are 2 approaches: on both, the user has a 'lost password' link available on the login page, or perhaps in Help. The user enters his/her email address and clicks a 'reset my password' button. Note that this requires the user to have a valid email address for this to work, and additionally sites may also want to restrict this functionality to user types which are internally authenticated (rather than authenticated against LDAP, etc.). Approach 1: As implemented and described by Rutgers, "On the main sakai page, before logging in, go to "New Account". There should be a new button on the bottom labelled "send password email". Specify the username of a guest (which must be an email address) in the userid field, and click the button. You should get an email with a URL that will log you in. At that point you can change your password or other information. (The token in the URL is actually the password MD5'd twice, the second time with a salt.)" i.e. the user is emailed a URL containing a token which takes the user to a page allowing the user to enter a new password. Approach 2: The user is emailed a new password, e.g. a randomly-generated numeric password. Approach 1 is probably preferable, as it provides more safeguards against abuse (e.g. someone entering someone else's password in 'lost password' and resetting the other user's password, which would not be a security vulnerability, but could be disruptive and annoying to the 'victim' user). Another complication would be in cases where more than 1 user has the same email address but distinct usernames - assuming that 'lost password' is checking on account email address as well as or instead of account id (for guest accounts, initially account id = email address, but users could change their email address to something different later). Approach 1 would also work better in that instance, as it would prevent user A from changing user B's password where both share the same email address. Alternately the 'lost password' form could require a username in addition to an email address.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-117] SMS (text messaging) integration
item.description:
In a number of countries, a very high percentage of students have cell phones (mobile phones) with text messaging capability (e.g. > 95% of students at University of Cape Town).

There are many applications for using text messaging to communicate with Sakai users both with the existing & future toolset, for example announcements and notifications, and for interactive learning applications such as submitting content or questions to possible tools such as a FAQ, Glossary tool, Forums or Wiki page by SMS.

Supporting SMS capability in Sakai requires:
- Profile tool to allow students to enter a cellphone number
- User preference settings to opt in or opt out of SMS notifications
- Integration with (minimally) Announcements and notification service
- Site option settings
- A service for passing outgoing messages to a gateway
- A service for accepting incoming messages from a gateway
- Quota management capabilities for setting volume limits for sites and users

The service and options available need to be flexible enough to cater for inter alia different types of SMS gateways in use, and different business models applicable in different countries (e.g. sender pays, receiver pays, etc.).
item.summary: SMS (text messaging) integration

comments.comment: Assigned to Stephen
Reassigned to Collab & Communications Tools oversight team
Some notes on UCT's proposed implementation are at https://www.connect.uct.ac.za/sakaiwiki/index.php/SMS
OK for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-119] Users should be able to upload a photo in Profile
item.description:
Presently, if a user wishes to add her photo to her profile, she needs to do the following:

- Upload an image into Resources
- Make the image public (share it)
- Add the URL of the image in Profile

To make this simpler for users, Profile should allow users to upload a photo, rather than specifying a URL. The uploaded image should also be automatically resized for an appropriate display size. Optionally, the original image could be retained along with the resized image.

Use Case:

* A TA wants to make his photo available to students, instructors, and other TAs in a course site. He goes to "Profile", clicks on "Upload Picture", and selects a JPG file on his desktop. The graphics file is uploaded and displayed to users who have authorization to see his personal information.
item.summary: Users should be able to upload a photo in Profile

comments.comment: This functionality should probably also contain some of the permission functionality described in other requirements (e.g., REQ-99) dealing with who can access a user's personal information
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-120] Renaming Tools Should be Reflected in Help Documentation
item.description:
The names of tools in help documentation needs to be configurable to match an institution's desire to rename tools.

Use Case:

* An institution decides to rename "Syllabus" to "Course Outline".


----------------------------
Original Description:

Two changes to the help tool:

- The current frames layout is clumsy. Specifically users have to resize the search / index frames when using either one. It would be preferable to have Index and Search as tabs, and a top banner which institutions can brand and customize. [This is more of a Featue Request for an alternate design that a new use case and is being dropped from this requirement.]

- When institutions rename tools (e.g. "Syllabus" to "Course Outline"), there is no easy way to have that name change reflected in the Help index and documents (or if this capacity exists, it is under-documented).
item.summary: Renaming Tools Should be Reflected in Help Documentation

comments.comment: Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-121] Add Hierarchy Capability to the Framework
item.description: This will add a generic hierarchy backbone within Sakai and allow sites, and other objects to be associated with theis hierarchy. The primary end-user visible aspect of this will be the ability to have sub-sites, or sites within sites. Over time, tools may begin to use the hierarchy capability to organize their own objects.
item.summary: Add Hierarchy Capability to the Framework

comments.comment: Would it be possible to restate the requirement in terms of its end goal rather than in terms of its implementation? That is: "Add ability to have sub-sites, or sites within sites." I'm concerned that specifying a generic design before the specific functional requirements may interfere with clarifying and optimizing the most common use cases.

Some preliminary views on hierarchy from Columbia's course management team. We can also supply some more specific cases, if necessary, to articulate this. - site hierarchy: Institutionally driven hierarchy, based on school, department, division, subject code, etc. This allows customization of appearance (skin, layout), default tool selection, and administrative access privileges. A pertinent example is our current CMS's course evaluation module that allows school- and department-wide evaluations and surveys. - content hierarchy: The ability to create sites and sites within sites, using user-based tools that automatically connect and embed one site within another. (One open question is whether you allow content to be "blended" as when two Intro sections get merged together. From some previous experience, we think this should be carefully considered with regard to support, implementation, and ease of use.) - tool hierarchy: the ability to create sites that have tools based on user-based decisions. For example, a user could design a single site template, then use that site as the starting point for all other sites.
Seth, by all means, please attach your specific use cases here; the more information the better!

Thanks, Seth. Again, though, I wonder if could we split the functional / administrative *requirements* from the assumption that anything modeled by a tree structure should be bundled in one place. Otherwise, I'm afraid that we risk polluting our analysis of the problem and then providing the wrong solution. We might describe your first "view" as requiring "access to and use of education *enterprise organizational data* by site management, authorization, and other Sakai services". There we're not talking about a tree of objects all of the same type, but a rich source of many different types of information, which happen to include some institutionally-defined person memberships and roles. This is the area targeted by the Course Management WG, and I hope we'll be able to wring lots of free labor out of your team. :) The second is talking about *web subsites*, with some TBD functionality for inheriting or restricting authorizations and views down a pseudo-directory-tree. This is a known need, but I don't think any work group is specifically targeting it yet. The third is a bit harder for me to get. I understand your example: *allow user-designed site templates*, which would presumably be easier to work with than making a "generic" site and then copying it to new sites, and which would presumably come into play during automatic creation of sites via enterprise integration. But I'm not sure how to generalize further than that.

From a usage data perspective, it would be useful to represent what is described here as a site hierarchy in the URLs. That way one can easily report on usage within a particular local enterprise organizational scheme by simply looking for a string in the URL, instead of having to look up individual site ids and manually group them.

During our user studies around course management, we've seen that some users of Moodle use Seth's 3rd use case (tool hiearchy) as a way to deal with sections. So, for a langauge class where there are numerous sections, all taught by seperate instructors but with the same basic curriculum, they create a site once and duplicate for each section. So they start with the same content, but once the semester starts each instructor may utilize the site a little differently. The interesting part is that in many cases there is also shared content (and not shared content) throughout the semester.

In Stellar, we have (using Seth's nomenclature) site hierarchy (with the site hierarchy represented in the URLs), content hierarchy (for sections), not really tool hierarchy. I can (plan to) give our experience of what turned out to actually be useful, what we didn't get around to implementing but wish we had, and what we wound up implementing in different ways.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-127] Improve support for Hibernate - Move hibernate aspects out of shared/lib
item.description:
Currently when a component uses Hibernate all of the Hibernate aspects of the component must move into shared/lib because of class loader issues. This also causes some problems when hibernate based components call each other.

This will require some careful thought to come up with a solution and then may require all of the Sakai components which use Hibernate to make some modifications to make use of the new pattern of Hibernate usage. Because of the need for release-wide coordination and the potentially large QA effort, this is something that the community should prioritize.

This may be combined with an update to Hibernate-3 and possibly a move to the latest Spring version.
item.summary: Improve support for Hibernate - Move hibernate aspects out of shared/lib

Come up with a strategy, design, and development effort to provide some form of integration with Moodle. A commonly discussed use case is to allow Moodle to be used from within Sakai using a variant of the IMS Tool Interoperability approach.

This would allow most of a Sakai site to be Sakai tools, but to be able to have buttons within a Sakai site be Moodle tools hosted on any Moodle server.

The key will be autoprivisioning of identity and roles between Sakai and Moodle.

item.title: [REQ-129] Support for Learning Design and other Work Flow Engines (such as LAMS)
item.description:
Sakai should be able to integrate with learning design and workflow engines. We need to refine the Sakai Architecture (likely the Entity Model) in order to support the workflow needs of a learning design engine such as LAMS or Coppercore. The requirements these engines have range from discovery of entities, the timed use of entities during Learning Design experiences, and the retrieval of information from entities.

Use Case:
An instructor wants to be able to create a workflow in a Sakai site. Once this support was added they could use a learning design and workflow engine to create a workflow and make it part of their Sakai site.
item.summary: Support for Learning Design and other Work Flow Engines (such as LAMS)

comments.comment: By Chuck: This will be a significant effort, starting with spending some time looking at LAMS and Coppercore's internal APIs and also the IMS LD spec. It is likely that it will take a long time to understand alll of the dimensions of this integration before work will actually start. Ready for voting

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-130] JSF Widget Cleanup
item.description:
One of the original visions of Sakai was to delegate much of the implementation of the presentation abstraction to JSF components.

Many projects have used JSF and used a blend of Sakai widgets and their own widgets.

We need to go through a carful effort of bringing these widgets back together so as to end up with a richer set of Sakai widgets so that we can use widgets across tools.

This is often a daunting task because it is more difficultt to write a highly generic variant of a widget versus one which is used in a single place - so some careful architecting is needed to be done in this effort.
item.summary: JSF Widget Cleanup

comments.comment: Just to add to the (temporary) dauntingness of it all, I'll add that the JSF world is in a mighty ferment, what with Oracle donating ADF Faces (the richest widget library by far) to MyFaces, the Facelets project, Struts Shale, and the pending JSF 1.2. In a few months, the work required to do a decent UI job in JSF may be cut by two-thirds or more. (The suspense is pretty painful.)
UI Group done with this one.

item.title: [REQ-135] Bidirectional email gateway for Message Forums
item.description:
In many cases, users wish to receive discussion items by email rather than logging in to a website daily or more often. Email Archive provides a way of using email discussion, but is too simple for many applications.

Users should therefore have the ability to participate in Forum discussions as if they were email-based mailing lists, i.e. subscribe to a discussion at various levels (forum, topic or thread). Once subscribed, user's are sent relevant forum postings.

Each email has an appropriate reply address allowing the user to reply to the message by email (in which case the message is inserted into the forum), and also has links which take the user directly to that thread in the forums tool (subject to the usual authentication).

Users can manage their email subscriptions with the forum tool, again either at a forum / topic / thread level, or by managing a list of all current subscriptions for the site.
item.summary: Bidirectional email gateway for Message Forums

comments.comment: I am assigning to Kristol to see if any of this funcationality is already on the Message Forum roadmap. I will look at the jForum functionality.
This functionality is not currently on our radar, so it is a good requirement to look into for future development.

item.title: [REQ-137] Hierarchy and date ranges for Syllabus
item.description:
Syllabus currently provides a reorderable flat view of items. In many cases, lecturers wish to group items according to:

1. Theme
2. Timeslot (e.g. weeks)

Syllabus should therefore be able to support hierarchies (either unlimited or to depth 3), and some relationship of items to dates, for example if an item is a Lecture, it would have a specific day associated with it. If an item is a week (Week 3), it may have a start and end date.

Syllabus item dates could optionally be added to the Schedule (Calendar). The Syllabus display could also be optimized to show current or forthcoming (near future) items, e.g. Current Week, Forthcoming lectures.

item.title: [REQ-138] Gradebook options to support moderating grades across sections
item.description:
In large courses (e.g. 500+ students) with many groups/sections and many different people grading assignments (e.g. TAs), institutional assessment policy may require that grades are moderated across groups, i.e. the grading behaviour of different graders should be consistent, and if not, grades possibly adjusted.

To facilitate this, the gradebook should provide a display and export option to produce a table for each assignment showing by group, the TA, and the highest, lowest and average grade given.

This allows a course convenor or assessment moderator to determine if grading has been consistent across groups, and to apply moderation strategies if required.

(The above is in US terminology; in South Africa, grades = marks, TAs = Tutors).
item.summary: Gradebook options to support moderating grades across sections

item.title: [REQ-151] Signup for a specific event within a course and assignment context
item.description:
Certain courses require individuals or teams to complete tasks in (for example) lab settings, where there are is a limited number of lab spaces available (and/or any other constrained resource, e.g. items of equipment).

Students are therefore required to signup for a specific event. Applicable business rules may include:

- Students must sign up in teams of up to X students. Team leaders may sign up themselves and their team members, or individuals may join an existing team which is not full.

- The event may be held in multiple sessions. Only a limited number of students can be accommodated in one session (e.g. a computer lab only has 20 PCs, but there are 60 students in the course, so students have a choice of 3 sessions).

This use case is more complex than students signing up for Sections, in that the events are once-off rather than repeating, and additional business rules may apply.

Lecturers can view the signup sheet for a session (in printable form), lock the session (to prevent additional signups), and enter a mark for all participants / teams in a session (submitted to Gradebook).
item.summary: Signup for a specific event within a course and assignment context

item.title: [REQ-163] Instructors should be able to assign site-specific aliases to users
item.description:
Currently, a user has one ID, one email address, one name, and so on across all sites within a Sakai installation. There should be a way to set site-specific user data which will be displayed instead of the defaults in the context of a given site. In particular, course-site-specific aliases should be able to override a student's user ID.

Use Cases:

* In a Trade Bargaining course, students are assigned country names. For the duration of the course they represent that country in all activities within the course, including voting, chatting, and discussions. In the equivalent course site, students are identified by country name aliases in all tools.

===

Original description:

We have a Trade Bargaining course where students are assigned country names and for the duration of the course they represent that country in all activities within the course.
For the last few years they've been using an online environment to do their bargaining, voting, chatting and discussions. Having access to an online environment has become essential to the course and they won't be able to use Sakai without this feature.
The alias should be course specific.
Also the students don't choose their alias, it is assigned to them
item.summary: Instructors should be able to assign site-specific aliases to users

comments.comment: I added more components to reflect the apparent scope of the requirement.
Greg, if the instructor goes to the Gradebook to give a student a final grade, should the instructor see the student's ID, or the country name alias, or both?
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

To the question (in the Gradebook to give a student a final grade, should the instructor see the student's ID, or the country name alias, or both?) ideally both, which is what we''ve been used to. In fact in all tools where the student id and name appears, the student id and alias should.

item.title: [REQ-165] Behavior Change for "Release Grades" function
item.description:
In the current system, if an instructor saves a draft of an assignment he or she is in the process of grading, and then clicks "Release Grades", the grade is still sent to the student.

1. Instructor - create an assignment
2. Student - submit the assignment
3. Instructor - enter a grade and comments for assignment, click "Preview", then click "Save draft"
4. Instructor - click "Release Grades"
5. Student - grade is displayed

The desired behavior from our perspective would be for ONLY grades that were RETURNED and not SAVED as a Draft. It seems that the option to SAVE as a Draft implies that the grading is still in progress and should not be returned back to the student when "Release Grades" is chosen.

A work around that may give more flexibility to this problem would be to allow the instructor the ability to set preferences for the Release Grades option, such that they can choose to release all grades or only returned grades.

This was originally bug SAK-3719
item.summary: Behavior Change for "Release Grades" function

comments.comment: Some type of dialogue box should pop up when the "Release Grades" option is clicked that more clearly describes what is going to occur. Alternatively, when the assignment scores are more closely integrated with the gradebook these releasing issues should probably be handled on the gradebook side. Once the integration is complete the "Release Grades" option could be retired completely from the Assignments tool.

The current functionality seriously inconveniences instructors (like myself) who may be using the assignments grading feature for the first time. I clicked "Release Grades" before I'd actually graded any assignments and then graded them afterward. Now that I've finished grading, the students cant see the grading because I clicked "Release Grades" before the assignments had actually been graded. Unless there is a way to release the grades again this functionality definitely needs to be changed or documented better.
Ready for voting.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Essential (Can use Sakai but need this ASAP)

item.title: [REQ-196] Import should allow instructors to replace existing items with imported items
item.description:
Goals:
Instructors can choose to replace existing items with imported items rather than always adding imported items to the data that's already there.

(Effectively, this combines cleaning out existing tool data with importing. It implies that tools which support "import" and "export" should also develop support for "replace".)

Use cases:

* An instructor wants to refresh parts of their course site rather than creating a new site. She chooses to import from another site's Announcements, Assignments, Discussion items, Resource items and Schedule. However, instead of having the relevant data be added to existing items, she selects the tool-by-tool option of overwriting the current data with the imported data.
item.summary: Import should allow instructors to replace existing items with imported items

comments.comment: Kristol, what sort of items did you have in mind here? Could you provide some examples by way of use cases? Thanks.

So, without adding an additional requirement of items that a user needs to be able to import, I'll try to explain this requirement in more detail. Currently, instructors can import Announcements, Assignments, Discussion items, Resource items and Schedule items. However, when an instructor imports these items, the items are added in addition to the items that have already been created in the site. Our instructors would like the ability to say that the items they are importing should replace the items that currently exist in the site rather than being added in addition to those items. Basically, they want to be able to choose whether the items should be added to or replace the existing items.
Thanks, that makes it easier to understand.
I added components to indicate the extent of the requirement.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-197] Instructors should be able to re-use section/group definitions
item.description:
Many different sites, with different memberships, may share an organizational hierarchy of sections and groups. There should be a way to re-use a set of section or site group names across sites without having to recreate the groups each time. This might be done by importing section/group definitions from an existing site, for example.

Use Cases:

* An Instructor is teaching 5 sections of the same class (Speech R110) and he consistently uses the same names for groups in his classes (e.g., Informational Speech, Demonstration Speech, Impromptu Speaking, Persuasive Speech and Commemorative Speech). Each time he creates a site, he imports these group names. The instructor then assigns the new site's students to the groups.
item.summary: Instructors should be able to re-use section/group definitions

comments.comment: Kristol, could you provide some use cases to illustrate the goal here? Thanks.

For example, if an Instructor is teaching 5 sections of the same class (Speech R110) and he consistently uses the same names for groups in his classes (e.g., Informational Speech, Demonstration Speech, Impromptu Speaking, Persuasive Speech and Commemorative Speech), then it would be beneficial for him to be able to easily import these groups into each site rather than taking the time to create the same groups in a multitude of sites. Only the shell of the group would import (i.e., the name) and the instructor could then enter each group and assign the necessary students to the group.

Interesting, so basically its re-using the organizational hierarchy or groups in a new site. Sort of like re-using the categories and topics from Discussion in a subsequent semester, but not the actual discussion messages from the students.
Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-198] Gradebook Statistical Display
item.description:
Provide statistics

Provide meaningful statistics on data entered in the gradebook for instructor and student review. Instructors should be able to specify whether or not students have this ability. This would be something that isn't displayed initially, but could be displayed.

At a glance, Instructors can see how the class is performing. If students have access, they can compare their performance to that of the class.

For students, the instructor should be able to see - at a glance -
1) Running grade as a letter (grade calculated based solely on assignments that have a grade entered - 0 vs null)
2) Running grade as a percent
3) Total points
4) points possible (which could vary from student to student depending on what assignments have entered grades)

In addition, on an assignment basis the following should be calculated and displayed
1) Average
2) Highest grade
3) Lowest grade
4) Standard deviation

All viewable on the same screen - right now the average can be viewed, but none of the student specific data is there for easy comparison.
item.summary: Gradebook Statistical Display

comments.comment: Assigning to Owen for review.
Ready for voting.
linking to REQ-198.

item.title: [REQ-208] Consistently use global action action links as tool navigation between pages. Currently, these buttons have different models in legacy tools and newer tools.
item.description:
Conistently use global action links as tool navigation between pages. This will allow users to build a consistent mental model about getting around in Sakai.

Allow users to use the global action links to move around to different pages within a tool in a consistent manner. Legacy and newer tools act differently. In new tools, the global action links (at the top of the page) are persistently available and take users to each page within the tool. In legacy tools there are a variety of results, sometimes they are used for navigation and others times they are used for actions. The global action links change depending on what on page you are in within the tool.

item.title: [REQ-210] Add Support for JSR-170 (Java Content Repository)
item.description:
Sakai should support JSR-170. This would allow Sakai to import content from repositories which are JSR-170 compliant and possibly allow content systems to display Sakai content as well.

JSR-170 or Content Repository API for Java (JCR) is a specification for a Java platform API for accessing content repositories in a uniform manner. The specification was developed under the Java Community Process. The objective of JSR-170 is to provide a standard content repository API facilitating vendor neutrality and interoperability. JSR-170 specifies a standard API to access content repositories in Java independently of implementation.

This is a long term effort and will need to be fit in within a sequence of significant framework changes. The rough approach should be to first evaluate possible solutions/implementations looking at Jakarta JackRabbit or other open source alternatives.
item.summary: Add Support for JSR-170 (Java Content Repository)

comments.comment: Ready for voting

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-211] Sakai should support authoring of public web pages
item.description:
Currently, the public face of a Sakai installation is the special "Gateway" site, and the public face of a Sakai site consists of a few pieces of data shown inside the "Sites" browser. Existing out-of-the-box Sakai tools aren't well set up to provide the kind of flexibility needed for easy production of "normal" web pages.

Sakai needs some web content management capability that is nicely integrated into Sakai's structure and organization.

Sakai should be able to produce an organization's public pages in addition to private site-oriented and personal pages.

Use Cases:

* The installation administrator creates a set of publicly accessible HTML pages describing their organization, including uploaded graphics. Visitors to that Sakai deployment see those pages before logging in.

* An instructor creates a course site and then adds a publicly accessible page, giving an overview of the course and providing links to interesting publicly accessible resources on the site. Non-site-members browsing the list of active sites see a link to that course site's public page.

===

Original description:

The Gateway page is pretty lame in general. This is one of the reasons that Sakai cannot be used to support www.sakaiproject.org. Sakai needs a content management capability that is nicely integrated into Sakai's structure and organization.

The basic use case is to use Sakai to produce an organization's public pages in addition to the private site oriented and personal pages.

Some technologies to consider include http://incubator.apache.org/graffito/ and http://hypercontent.sourceforge.net/.
item.summary: Sakai should support authoring of public web pages

comments.comment: Reviewed by Worksite & Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-212] Search for users widget
item.description:
Sakai should provide support for a consistent "user search" widget. This widget would allow users to search for other users and user-related information, where such information needs to be input in a tool; for example, finding users in order to add them to a site. The searchable content and results should be able to include any basic user information that is stored in Sakai or to which Sakai has access through an external provider; however, it may only be necessary to present a sub-set of that information in any given search context. The sub-set may also need to be limited based on the searcher's role and/or site type in order to satisfy privacy concerns. The results of the search should also enable the seacher to easily choose a user or group of users(or the context-appropriate piece of user information, such as email address) and use it as input for the tool.

Use cases:

* When adding users to a site, you may know the user's name or only part of their name, but not their username, and you need to search a directory of users to find the username. Once you have it, you want it entered into "add user" field.

* Similarly in Section Info you may need to search for users for which you only have partial information to add them to a section.
item.summary: Search for users widget

comments.comment: Individual privacy comes to my mind. When we did our LDAP enterprise directory (not related to Sakai), we had to allow individuals to hide certain bits of information (home address for instance) from internet and intranet view. There's potentially a lot of information that can come through an SIS feed. I suppose if you already have a University intranet policy of what can be displayed (core data like campus id,first name, middle name,last name), that would be applicable to what could be returned to through the search widget. If you could return MORE information that what's available from an intranet directory search that could lead Sakai to be abused for searching.
Added to membership and profile components - seems related to me.

Agreed on the privacy concerns. This is meant to be used in places where users information is required to complete a task, like, adding participants to a site. Currently, to add a participant to a site, users have to leave Sakai, to do a search on the the University directory, and then copy and paste the persons email address or institutional ID into the text box. My guess is it would use the LDAP directory where available so the privacy would be built in. This would be a huge time saver.
Reviewed by Worksite and Admin Tools.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Desirable (Can use Sakai but would like this)

item.title: [REQ-213] Schedule should allow for creating new items in the context of the calendar.
item.description:
Allow users to choose the date and time of an event in the context of the calendar (like most calendar systems).

Allow users to drag events around on the calendar to change the date and time of the event.

Allow users to change the duration of an event by directly manipulating the event on the calendar.


Another requirement from UC Berkeley with Essential priority (within one year):

"Currently the schedule tool requires users to navigate to a separate window to enter a new calendar event. The norm in many calendars is to click and drag to select the duration of a meeting, or double-clcik a timeframe in the calendar interface to begin adding or editing an entry.

The schedule tool should allow users to click the time the wish to schedule an event to bring up an editing window.

This is similar to functionality available in other calendar tools like iCal, Outlook, and Oracle."
item.summary: Schedule should allow for creating new items in the context of the calendar.

Usage data could be used to inform presentation (e.g. display by most frequently accessed words), and for instructor feedback.

More complex uses could involve using the glossary to overlap course content, highlighting words which are defined in the glossary so that users can access popup definitions, and/or integration with tools such as the wiki (e.g. a macro such as {glossary:someword}

item.title: [REQ-218] Integration with Respondus
item.description:
Respondus (http://www.respondus.com/) is a program one uses in creating and managing exams that can be printed to paper or published directly to Blackboard, WebCT, eCollege, ANGEL and other eLearning systems.

i.e. you can create quizzes in Respondus, connect to your CMS from within Respondus and upload the questions to a particular course. You can also download questions and quizzes from the CMS.

It also has the ability to export quizzes in IMS QTI format.

Our stats department are heavy users of Respondus and if it possible to have the same ability to upload questions/quizzes directly to Sakai it would make the migration easier.

Going the IMS QTI route is possible, but only if the questions do not contain images. This is filed under another requirement. (REQ-217)

Also see http://bugs.sakaiproject.org/jira/browse/SAK-1891

comments.comment: A good Respondus-like tool not only allows the instructor to upload questions using a simple syntax directly from a Web page, it also allows the instructor to append questions to an existing question set or overwrite that set. At our school instructors prefer to use the Respondus-like tool over the GUI question builder for editing questions because question creation/modication proceeds much faster. We use Respondus with WebCT's assessment tool but what is even more popular with our instructors is having a Respondus-like tool built directly into one's assessment tool rather than having to install a local client.
